Dear Sir:

On January 11th a draft agreement covering the transportation of the Indian children to and from the new Cowichan Consolidated Day School was forwarded to the Department. The proposed agreement covers a five year period but subject to cancellation by the Department upon 90 days' notice. Since forwarding the agreement I have given further consideration to the matter and I should like to suggest that it might be as well not to sign a contract with the Kyle Taxi Co. extending beyond the end of the present school year. It is intended to review the Consolidated School administration at the close of the term in June, and the question of transportation could then also be reviewed as well and a change made if considered desirable.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT made this Nineteenth day of December in the year of our Lord One thousand nine hundred and thirty-nine BETWEEN: HIS MAJESTY THE KING IN THE RIGHT OF CANADA AS REPRESENTED BY THE DIRECTOR OF THE INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH OF THE DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES hereinafter called "the Department" of the one part and J. A. KYLE of the City of Duncan in the Province of British Columbia carrying on business as Cowichan Valley Bus and Taxi Services (Kyle) and HOWARD VALENTINE KYLE of the said City of Duncan (hereinafter called "the Contractors") of the other part.

WHEREAS the Department is required to provide for the transportation to and from school of certain school children

AND WHEREAS in the pursuance of such requirement the Department has entered into an arrangement with the Contractors for such means of transportation and these presents are for the purpose of setting out the terms and conditions of the agreement entered into by the parties hereto

NOW THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that it is agreed by and between the respective parties hereto the Contractors agreeing jointly and severally as follows:

1. The Contractors shall inaugurate and maintain during the period commencing on the 1st day of January 1940 and terminating on the 30th day of June 1945 (both days being included in the period) a motor vehicle service for the purpose of conveying and shall convey in a motor vehicle or motor vehicles to and from such school or schools as the Department shall from time to time designate and notify to the Contractors within the boundaries of the Cowichan Indian Reserve such children as shall
from time to time be designated by the Department or its Agent and notified by it to the Contractors.

2. Subject to Section II(d) of the Regulations under the "Motor-Vehicle Act" set forth in an Order of the Lieutenant-Governor in Council dated the 18th day of April 1935 each child shall be taken on board the vehicle on its way to the school and shall be permitted to alight on the return journey from the school at such points on the said route as may from time to time be designated by the Department.

3. The Contractors shall maintain the service along the following routes that is to say:

A.M. Leave the Somence Indian village on the Cowichan Indian Reserve proceeding northerly along the Island Highway turning east on to the trunk road and Victoria road to the new Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School, thence via the old Victoria road through the Cowichan Indian Reserve to the Island Highway, thence westerly along said highway to the Koksilah Mission road, thence north to Koksilah Mission near the Koksilah Indian School, thence returning over the same route to the said Consolidated Indian Day School.

P.M. Leave the said Consolidated Indian Day School and proceed via the old Victoria road and Cowichan Indian Reserve and the Island Highway, thence westerly to the Koksilah Mission road, thence north to Koksilah Mission near Koksilah Indian School, thence returning by the same route to said Consolidated Indian Day School, thence west to said Somence Indian Village via the old Victoria road to the Island Highway as per plan attached.

4. The Contractors shall maintain such service on each and every school day during the currency of this agreement and shall so time the passage of the vehicle along the route reasonably so as to deliver and the Contractors shall deliver the passengers at the schools so designated as aforesaid not later than 8:55 o'clock in the forenoon of each school day and shall have the vehicle at the schools to take up the passengers at such times in the afternoon as shall be designated by the Department or its Agent in the afternoon of each school day.

5. When proceeding along the route the driver of the vehicle shall sound a distinctive warning by horn or otherwise when approaching any point at which any child or children is or are in the habit of entering the vehicle and shall use all proper and reasonable means to ensure the transportation to and from a school of all children so designated as aforesaid.

6. The Contractors shall comply with all and every the provisions of the Motor-Vehicle Act (Revised Statutes of British Columbia 1956 Chapter 195) and any amendments thereto now or hereafter in force and applicable and in particular shall comply with the said Regulations set forth in the said Order of the Lieutenant-Governor in Council and any other regulations and orders now or which may hereafter from time to time be in force and applicable.

7. The Contractors shall maintain a good safe efficient and punctual service and shall equip and operate all vehicles in such manner as will ensure the reasonable comfort and shelter of the passengers therein PROVIDED ALWAYS that the Contractors

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6388, File 807-5, part 3)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
shall not be bound to maintain the service upon any route during such time as it shall be rendered impassable or dangerous by reason of deep snow or other cause beyond the control of the Contractors but the Contractors shall not be entitled to any remuneration during such time.

6. The Contractors shall at the Contractors' own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in respect of each vehicle against public liability and against loss of life and injury to the children who may be passengers in any vehicle and any person carried therein accompanying or in charge of such children or any of them in an Insurance Company or Insurance Companies approved by the Department and such insurance shall cover the Contractors and all or any liability of the Department in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the claim of any one individual and in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one accident and in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for damage to property and the Contractors shall punctually pay all premiums in respect of such insurance and deliver the receipts for such premiums to the Department and produce the policies to the Department for inspection upon demand.

7. The Contractors shall also at the Contractors' own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in favour of the Department against non-owners liability in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for or in respect of any legal liability of the Department for bodily injury to or the death of any one person and subject to
such limit for any one person so injured or killed in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident and any policy for such insurance shall also extend to and cover all school children their attendants or teachers while being transported to or from school to or from games and to or from outings in the personal charge of the Department or in a motor vehicle operated by the Contractors. The premium for such insurance shall be paid by the Contractors and all and every policy for such insurance shall be in the name of the Department.

10. The Contractors shall employ as drivers of vehicles competent chauffeurs of good moral character and shall cease to employ any person as driver or assistant on any vehicle if so requested in writing by the Department.

11. The Contractors shall maintain the service solely for the transportation of children to and from school as aforesaid and no person other than the chauffeur or an employee of the Contractors' assistant to the chauffeur or any teacher or teachers in the employ of the Department shall be permitted to be on board any vehicle at any time while engaged in such service.

12. The remuneration to be paid by the Department to the Contractors for the service hereunder shall be calculated as follows:

The sum of thirty-five (35) cents per mile per day for all children up to the number of thirty (30) and for the purpose of calculating such remuneration the said route shall be deemed to measure thirty-two (32) miles inclusive of the inward and return trips twice a day, the Contractor to submit

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6388, File 807-5, part 3)

his account for the service at the end of each month for payment, subject to any adjustment or correction by the Department.

THE CONTRACTORS shall transport any children over and above the number prescribed for any route if the vehicle in use has sufficient capacity therefor but shall not be entitled to any further remuneration for any children above the prescribed number so transported PROVIDED ALWAYS that in the event of the circumstances prescribed in the Schedule hereto taking place in respect of either of the said Routes the said remuneration may be varied from time to time upon notice in writing given by either party hereto to the other party and thereupon such variation shall take place as from the date of service of such notice calculated in accordance with provisions applicable as set forth in the said Schedule.

15. The service shall not be continued and the said remuneration shall not be payable during the usual school vacations nor shall the service be continued nor shall the remuneration be payable during any period other than the said vacations when the schools shall be closed.

16. The Department shall have power from time to time to change any route by any variation extension or modification thereof PROVIDED that in the event of any such extension the Department shall pay to the Contractor as remuneration an additional amount per mile or part of a mile by which the route is so extended calculated at the rate provided in Clause 12 hereof in respect of such route and in the event of any modification of a route the remuneration of the Contractors shall be reduced.
by an amount per mile or part of a mile by which the route is so modified calculated at the rate provided in Clause 12 hereof in respect of such route and in the event of any dispute as to the measurement of any such extension or modification such measurement shall be ascertained by a British Columbia Land Surveyor whose fees shall be paid as to one-half thereof by the Department and as to the remaining one-half thereof by the Contractors.

15. Subject to Clause 14 hereof it is agreed that in the event of any dispute difference or question arising between the said parties hereto out of the construction or carrying out of the terms of these presents the same shall be referred to Arbitration pursuant to the Arbitration Act.

16. The remuneration payable to the Contractor shall be paid to them by the Department direct by cheque or to such person or persons corporation or corporations as the Contractors may from time to time request the Department in writing PROVIDED ALWAYS that nothing herein contained shall have effect as permitting the Contractors to assign or transfer their obligations under this agreement.

17. The Department shall have the option of cancelling this agreement at any time by ninety days notice to the Contractors by notice sent by registered mail addressed to him at Duncan, British Columbia.

18. Wherever the context so requires or admits the expression "the Contractors" hereinbefore used shall extend to and include the survivor of them to the intent and so that the obligations

-7-

hereby imposed upon or assumed by the Contractors shall be binding upon and performed by such survivor.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, on behalf of the Minister, and the Contractors have hereunto set their hands and seals the day and year first above written.

The Schedule above referred to

The remuneration of 35 (thirty-five) cents per mile payable to the Contractors as their remuneration in respect of designated routes shall be deemed to be based upon the rate of forty (40) cents per mile set under the authority of the Highways Act (R.S.B.C., 1956 Chap. 116) as Vancouver Island Charter rates for "over 20 Passenger Busses" consequently the said remuneration in respect of designated routes shall be varied upon any alteration of the said rate in the same proportion to the amount by which such rate is varied as 35¢ per mile bears to 40¢ per mile.

in the presence of

Ottawa,
January 22, 1940.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR
Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Cowichan Indian Day School

I am in receipt of your memorandum of January 16 enclosing copies of correspondence from your chief engineer with reference to certain improvements that might be made at the above-mentioned school.

Owing to shortage of funds the Department is only prepared to consider erection of the additional toilets and urinal. It is noted that the expenditure in this regard will not exceed $150.00.

Director.
Ottawa,
January 22, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the 11th and 15th instant with reference to the transportation of children to and from the new Cowichan Consolidated Day School. It is noted that you have made arrangements with the Cowichan Valley Bus and Taxi Services for the six-month period ending June 30, 1940.

In view of the recommendation contained in your letter of the 15th instant a contract with the Kyle Taxi Co. will not be signed at the present time. We will await further communication from you which, no doubt, will be forwarded some time in June.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.
January 17, 1940.

February 1st, 1940.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

With reference to your memorandum of the 22nd ultimo, regarding the installation of two additional toilets at the Indian Day School, Cowichan Reserve, B.C., I am enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of a memorandum from the Chief Engineer, in which it is to be noted that Mr. Webb has been authorized to proceed with the installation of the additional toilets and urinal, with fence and walk, using Indian labour, the total cost not to exceed his estimate of $139.00.

Director.
January 27, 1940.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Indian Day School,
Cowichan Reserve, B.C.

With reference to your memorandum of the 24th instant regarding installation of two additional toilets at the above, I may say that as the estimated cost of this work, utilizing Indian labour, is lower than the price quoted by the Contractor, and as the Contractor has completed all his work with the exception of the installation of the water supply hydrant, it is considered advisable to have this work carried out by day labour. We are, therefore, authorizing Mr. Webb to proceed with the installation of the additional toilets and urinal, with fence and walk, at a total cost not to exceed his estimate of $139.00.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

Chief Engineer.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Operation of Bus -
Cowichan Indian Day School

I have for acknowledgment Mr. Bethune's memorandum of February 8, in which he seeks information with respect to the contract entered into between this Department and the Cowichan Valley Bus and Taxi Service Company, with respect to the transportation of pupils at the above noted school.

I am sending forward herewith, for your information, copies of correspondence relating to the operation of the bus at this school. All of this correspondence, you will note, is self-explanatory.

In a letter to Indian Agent R. H. Moore, dated September 13, 1939, Mr. J. A. Kyle, Proprietor, Cowichan Valley Bus and Taxi Service, expressed willingness to enter into a contract to supply a thirty (30) passenger bus service for a six months' period - January 1 to June 30, 1940. The same offer was made by the Vancouver Island Coach Lines, Limited. It was felt, however, that the period was somewhat short, even for experimental purposes, and in my memorandum to you dated November 8, 1939, a period of approximately 18 months was suggested. However, the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia - Major D. M. MacKay - in a letter dated January 15, 1940, copy of which is enclosed, suggested that in view of all the circumstances, in his judgment it would not be advisable to extend the contract
with the Kyle Taxi Company beyond the end of the present school year (June 30, 1940). It is, apparently, the intention of the Commissioner to undertake a complete review of the operation of this school, including the transportation facilities, at the end of the present academic year.

I can see no serious objection to the Department entering into a contract for the longer period, provided a 30 day cancellation clause is inserted in the contract. The period was changed on the recommendation of the Indian Commissioner.

Director.

RAH
P. O. Box 70,
Vancouver, January 15, 1940.

Dear Sir:

On January 11th a draft agreement covering the transportation of the Indian children to and from the new Cowichan Consolidated Day School was forwarded to the Department. The proposed agreement covers a five year period but subject to cancellation by the Department upon 90 days' notice. Since forwarding the agreement I have given further consideration to the matter and I should like to suggest that it might be as well not to sign a contract with the Kyle Taxi Co. extending beyond the end of the present school year. It is intended to review the Consolidated School administration at the close of the term in June, and the question of transportation could then also be reviewed as well and a change made if considered desirable.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd. D. M. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B. C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
P. O. Box 70,
Vancouver, 11th Jan. 1940.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 5th ultimo, regarding transportation of pupils to the new Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School and acceptance of the offer of the Cowichan Valley Bus and Taxi Services, for the ensuing six-month period, which you stated you would prefer to cover a longer period unless there were reasons to the contrary, I would advise that I had the Inspector of Indian Agencies go into this matter when he was in Duncan recently, and he found that the Duncan School Board was employing this firm on a five-year contract, and securing their copy of the agreement, he drafted a similar agreement modified to meet our conditions, also inserting a clause (Section 17) enabling the Department to cancel the contract on ninety days' notice. While it is considered that the Department's interests are fully protected, it would be appreciated if the proposed contract receives careful consideration. Meanwhile, the transportation of the children is fully arranged for until the end of this term, in June, in accordance with your instructions of the 5th ultimo.

The proposed contract would expire on 30th June, 1945, and would, therefore, be effective for five and one-half years, including the present term. The signature of the contractors was secured, as it was anticipated that any changes in costs would tend to be on the increase than otherwise, under conditions that are likely to prevail for some time.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School,
Cowichan Indian Agency, Electoral
District of Nanaimo, B. C.

Provision for the erection of this school was made in the current year's appropriation and it is expected that the building will be completed for the middle of December.

As the majority of the children attending the school live at a considerable distance from it arrangements will have to be made for their transportation.

Indian Commissioner MacKay has given the matter very careful consideration and has submitted two propositions, one for the purchase of a bus by the Department and its operation by a man engaged by us or transportation by one of the local motor transportation companies.

Commissioner MacKay, after carefully considering both the above alternatives, writes, in part as follows:

"Even if it should finally be established that the cost of operating a Departmental bus would actually be less than herein shown there is still the very great responsibility involved in the transportation of a large group of children to be considered. Careful consideration of the various angles of the transportation problem confronting us based on the information gathered leads me to..."
conclude that it would be safer, more satisfactory and as economical for us to make arrangements with one of the transportation companies for the transportation of the children.

Commissioner MacKay has submitted quotations for this service from the following firms:

1. Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Service, Duncan, B. C.
2. Vancouver Island Coach Lines Ltd., Duncan, B. C.

Each of these companies quotes the same price; namely, 35¢ a mile for a bus that would contain 30 passengers. The bus would have to travel 16 miles in the morning to pick up the children and the same distance in the afternoon to return them to their homes.

Both companies offer the same terms as regards insurance protecting the passengers in the case of accident.

I should appreciate it if you would advise me as soon as possible with which company you would prefer our completing arrangements. I might add that it is our intention to arrange for the service for the period January 1, 1940, to June 30, 1941.

H. W. McGill,
Director.
COWICHAN VALLEY BUS & TAXI SERVICES

Duncan, B. C.,
September 19, 1939.

R. H. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B. C.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your memo of Saturday last and our conversation of this morning, I checked the mileage on the proposed school route for Indian children and find same to be sixteen (16) miles, making a total of thirty-two (32) miles per day, or one hundred sixty (160) miles per school week.

I am prepared to contract for a thirty (30) passenger bus for this work for six (6) months at the rate of thirty five cents (.35¢) per mile or a school week price of Fifty-six ($56.00) Dollars which would bring the price for the six (6) months period to One Thousand Three Hundred and Forty-four ($1344.00) Dollars.

Insurance carried will cover Five and Twenty Thousand ($5/20000) Dollars Public Liability for any one accident and One Thousand ($1000.00) Dollars for Property Damage and the Indian Department can be shown on the Insurance Policy so as to clear them of any Liability while children are in transit. It would also be understood that any day the service did not operate no compensation would be claimed.

Hoping to hear from you at your convenience,

I remain,

Yours truly,

(sgd.) J. A. Kyle,

Proprietor, Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Services.
VANCOUVER ISLAND COACH LINES Limited

Duncan V. I., September 20, 1939.

R. H. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Post Office Building,
Duncan, V. I.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your enquiry regarding the establishment of a school bus service to cover the new Cowichan Day School and the Koksilah Day School, we are pleased to submit herewith our tender as follows:

We are to provide one thirty passenger bus each school day. This bus would hold up to 36 children, would comply with the provisions of the Motor Vehicle Act of British Columbia governing the operation of school buses.

This coach to leave the White Bridge on the Somenos Reserve at approximately 8:05 a.m. and proceed to the new Cowichan Day School. From that point to proceed to the Koksilah School via the White Bridge and thence to the Cowichan Day School via the Tzouhalem Road. This route to be reserved in the afternoon at approximately 3:10 p.m.

Any contract entered into to go into effect on the first school day after January 1st, 1940, and to be for a period of six months expiring June 30, 1940, with an option of renewal.

For your information, we wish to advise that we carry insurance on every piece of equipment we operate for Public Liability in limits of $20,000.00 for death or injury to one person and $100,000.00 for death or injury to two or more persons in any one accident and a limit of $5,000.00 for property damage. This insurance coverage would apply to any or all buses operated by us on this proposed school contract.

For the above service, we hereby tender in the amount of $11.20 per day or $56.00 per week.

We wish -
We wish to thank you for allowing us the opportunity to quote on this contract, and trust that we may be favoured with your further instructions herein.

Yours very truly,

VANCOUVER ISLAND COACH LINES LTD.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR MONTH OF JANUARY 1940.

The new Cowichan Indian day school opened on the 8th of the month, and while it was more or less of a makeshift during the first few weeks, owing to lack of seating arrangements, equipment, school supplies etc. etc. nevertheless the Teachers did a very good job of it on the whole, although they were certainly working at a great disadvantage. The mud that was carried into the school was inches thick and the dust got all over all the nice painted woodwork causing a lot of damage and spoiling the appearance generally. The floors have not been helped by the mud either, and if I had known as much one month ago as I know now I would have advised keeping the school closed until the grounds were fixed or dried up.

R. H. Moore,
Indian Agent.
Memorandum:

Re: Indian Day School,
Cowichan Reserve, B.C.

Further to my memorandum of the 6th ultimo forwarding a report regarding certain improvements suggested for the school grounds at the above, Mr. Webb in a recent letter writes as follows:

"Last week while on Vancouver Island I had an opportunity to visit the new Cowichan Indian School which we have recently completed near Duncan.

The school itself has been well built and has a pleasing appearance. The finishing both inside and out including the paint job is entirely satisfactory. The grounds, however, are in an appalling state with about two or three inches of mud everywhere surrounding the building. The School was put in use almost immediately it was finished and the mud is being daily tracked into the building which is altogether unfortunate."

It is felt that the Indian Affairs Branch should take up this matter with the Indian Agent and that temporary walks should be provided to protect the School until arrangements can be made for the required improvements to the school grounds.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,

MEMORANDUM:

Re - Bus service Indian Day School,
Cowichan Reserve.

I have examined the draft agreement between the Crown and Kyle Brothers with regard to supplying the above service. The following items should, I think, be considered -

1. Page 2, section 3. The service is described, near the end of the paragraph, as "thence north to Koksilah Mission near the Koksilah Indian School". "Near" seems to be rather vague. I am not aware of the particular circumstances but I should think that the term should be more carefully defined.

2. Page 4. I am not clear as to the need for this clause providing non-ownership liability insurance as there is no legal liability on the Crown and the Insurance Company would probably raise this defence if an action were brought. If we made payment on compassionate grounds we could not collect the insurance but Mr. Finlayson would be better qualified to advise on this than I am.

3. Page 5, end of paragraph 9. In the 4th line from the bottom the second word is "or". Is not this a typographical error for "while"?

4. Page 5, paragraph 10. I would suggest that the words "and assistants" be inserted after the word "drivers" in the first line of the paragraph and putting the words "at once" after the word "and" in the second line.

5. Page 7, paragraph 17. I would suggest that this paragraph be amended to provide that "if any of the conditions in paragraphs 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 and 11 are not complied with by the contractor the contract shall terminate forthwith without notice and no action for damages shall lie against His Majesty." Violation of some of the conditions in the above cited paragraphs
would be very serious from the Department's point of view and if we could not enforce their rectification except by giving a 90-day notice the results might be very serious.

A point worth bearing in mind is this. If notice to cancel the contract was given at the beginning of June in any year while the contract would terminate at the end of August before the beginning of the next school year, under clause 13 we would only pay to the end of June as July and August are vacation months.

Senior Solicitor.

Sir:

March 1st, 1940.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter, File No. 152-22-5, dated February 24th, ultimo, in connection with domestic science supplies required for the Cowichan Consolidated School.

I wish to advise that I have not received any request from the Provincial Superior of the St. Ann's Academy Victoria, B.C., for necessary supplies.

I have however, on many occasions, discussed this question with the Principal of the School, and feel that a sum of $10.00 per month will be sufficient to supply the necessary hot drink and soup for the children during the School noon hour with which to augment the lunch they bring themselves.

Then of course there is the utensils that are necessary to properly instruct the children in plain and ordinary cooking, none of which the Domestic Teacher has so far received. Neither has she received any grant with which to purchase simple ingredients with which to teach, the result being that the whole domestic training just does not exist.

A requisition will be sent you again in a few days asking for the necessary pots and other cooking utensils which are essential to have before teaching cooking can be taught. I can assure you that this will be kept down to a minimum.

I would strongly recommend however, that an amount of $5.00 monthly be provided for the use of the domestic science Teacher to buy supplies with which to cook. This amount to be over and above the $10.00 requested for a hot drink and soup for the children during noon hour. It will I'm sure surprise you to know that out of one class-room alone in this School this week there were 30 pupils absent solely on account of getting wet feet and getting sick with colds and flu, many of them had to be sent to Hospital.

Yours obediently,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

AGENT'S REPORT ON COWICHAN AGENCY FOR FEBRUARY 1940.

Conditions at the Cowichan Consolidated day school were very bad during the month on account of wet grounds and a sea of mud and water around the building. Its most serious effect was on the health of the children who really suffered a great deal from wet feet, with the resultant colds and Flu. At one particular time there were 30 children from once class room absent on account of being sick with colds etc. some of them having to be sent to the hospital. To my mind these colds were the direct result of wet feet. We are hoping that within the next two or three weeks the grounds will dry up enough to allow the children to get outside during the recess periods.

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.
Sir:

Re: Your File 182-22-5, Cowichan Indian Day School.

I thank you for your letter above noted and dated February 28th, 1940, regarding graveling a part of the grounds of the above school to prevent the tracking of mud into the School.

In this connection I wish to state that I have taken action in this matter but instead of putting down the gravel I got some rough planks from the local lumber yard to make walks from the school to the toilets. These planks will just be laid end to end, not cut up at all, so that the pupils can walk on them. The walk from the road to the building itself has been gravelled for some time so that it is quite alright, but between the building and the toilets is by far the worst and as the ground there is so loose, gravel would not do much good as it would go out of sight in a very few days, then it would be impossible to get a truck with a load of gravel on to the grounds as the whole place is so soft that it would get bogged. Furthermore, if and when the grounds are graded the gravel would be lost while the planks will be always useful and can be utilized for some other purpose after grading has been done, and finally the cost of the planks will not be any more than gravel would cost. I might say in closing that I discussed this with the Indian Commissioner and he felt that the planks would be more satisfactory, especially as the cost would not be any more. Trusting that these arrangements will meet with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary;
Indian Affairs Branch.
Ottawa.

A. KYLE of the City of Duncan in the Province of British Columbia carrying on business as Cowichan Valley Bus and Taxi Services (Kyle) and HOWARD VALENTINE KYLE of the said City of Duncan (hereinafter called "the Contractors") of the other part.

WHEREAS the Department is required to provide for the transportation to and from school of certain school children

AND WHEREAS in the pursuance of such requirement the Department has entered into an arrangement with the Contractors for such means of transportation and these presents are for the purpose of setting out the terms and conditions of the agreement entered into by the parties hereto

NOW THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that it is agreed by and between the respective parties hereto the Contractors agreeing jointly and severally as follows:-

1. The Contractors shall inaugurate and maintain during the period commencing on the 1st day of January 1940 and terminating on the 30th day of June 1945 (both days being included in the period) a motor vehicle service for the purpose of conveying and shall convey in a motor vehicle or motor vehicles to and from such school or schools as the Department shall from time to time designate and notify to the Contractors within the boundaries of the Cowichan Indian Reserve such children as shall
from time to time be designated by the Department or its Agent
and notified by it to the Contractors

2. Subject to Section 21(d) of the Regulations under the
"Motor-Vehicle Act" set forth in an Order of the Lieutenant-
Governor in Council dated the 18th day of April 1935 each child
shall be taken on board the vehicle on its way to the school and
shall be permitted to alight on the return journey from the
school at such points on the said route as may from time to time
be designated by the Department

3. The Contractors shall maintain the service along the follow-
ing routes that is to say:-

A. M. Leave the Somenos Indian village on the Cowichan
Indian Reserve proceeding northerly along the Island Highway
turning east on to the Trunk road and Victoria road to the
new Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School, thence via the
old Victoria road through the Cowichan Indian Reserve to the
Island Highway, thence westerly along said highway to the
Koksilah Mission road, thence north to Koksilah Mission near
the Koksilah Indian School, thence returning over the same
route to the said Consolidated Indian Day School

P. M. Leave the said Consolidated Indian Day School and
proceed via the old Victoria road and Cowichan Indian Reserve
and the Island Highway, thence westerly to the Koksilah
Mission road, thence north to Koksilah Mission near Koksilah
Indian School, thence returning by the same route to said
Consolidated Indian Day School, thence west to said Somenos
Indian Village via the old Victoria road to the Island High-
way as per plan attached
4. The Contractors shall maintain such service on each and every school day during the currency of this agreement and shall so time the passage of the vehicle along the route reasonably so as to deliver and the Contractors shall deliver the passengers at the schools so designated as aforesaid not later than 8:55 o'clock in the forenoon of each school day and shall have the vehicle at the schools to take up the passengers at such times in the afternoon as shall be designated by the Department or its Agent in the afternoon of each school day and shall proceed forthwith to transport and shall transport each of them to his or her destination along the route.

5. When proceeding along the route the driver of the vehicle shall sound a distinctive warning by horn or otherwise when approaching any point at which any child or children is or are in the habit of entering the vehicle and shall use all proper and reasonable means to ensure the transportation to and from a school of all children so designated as aforesaid.

6. The Contractors shall comply with all and every the provisions of the Motor-Vehicle Act (Revised Statutes of British Columbia 1936 Chapter 195) and any amendments thereto now or hereafter in force and applicable and in particular shall comply with the said Regulations set forth in the said Order of the Lieutenant-Governor in Council and any other regulations and orders now or which may hereafter from time to time be in force and applicable.

7. The Contractors shall maintain a good safe efficient and punctual service and shall equip and operate all vehicles in such manner as will ensure the reasonable comfort and shelter of the passengers therein PROVIDED ALWAYS that the Contractors
shall not be bound to maintain the service upon any route during such time as it shall be rendered impassable or dangerous by reason of deep snow or other cause beyond the control of the Contractors but the Contractors shall not be entitled to any remuneration during such time.

8. The Contractors shall at the Contractors' own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in respect of each vehicle against public liability and against loss of life and injury to the children who may be passengers in any vehicle and any person carried therein accompanying or in charge of such children or any of them in an Insurance Company or Insurance Companies approved by the Department and such insurance shall cover the Contractors and all or any liability of the Department in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the claim of any one individual and in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one accident and in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for damage to property and the Contractors shall punctually pay all premiums in respect of such insurance and deliver the receipts for such premiums to the Department and produce the policies to the Department for inspection upon demand.

9. The Contractors shall also at the Contractors' own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in favour of the Department against non-owners liability in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for or in respect of any legal liability of the Department for bodily injury to or the death of any one person and subject to
such limit for any one person so injured or killed in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident and any policy for such insurance shall also extend to and cover all school children their attendants or teachers while being transported to or from school to or from games and to or from outings in the personal charge of the Department while in a motor vehicle operated by the Contractors. The premiums for such insurance shall be paid by the Contractors and all and every policy for such insurance shall be in the name of the Department.

10. The Contractors shall employ as drivers and assistants of vehicles competent chauffeurs of good moral character and at once shall cease to employ any person as driver or assistant on any vehicle if so requested in writing by the Department.

11. The Contractors shall maintain the service solely for the transportation of children to and from school as aforesaid and no person other than the chauffeur or an employee of the Contractors' assistant to the chauffeur or any teacher or teachers in the employ of the Department shall be permitted to be on board any vehicle at any time while engaged in such service.

12. The remuneration to be paid by the Department to the Contractors for the service hereunder shall be calculated as follows:

The sum of thirty-five (35) cents per mile per day for all children up to the number of thirty (30) and for the purpose of calculating such remuneration the said route shall be deemed to measure thirty-two (32) miles inclusive of the inward and return trips twice a day, the Contractor to submit

The Contractors shall maintain such service on each and every school day during the currency of this agreement and shall so time the passage of the vehicle along the route reasonably so as to deliver and the Contractors shall deliver the passengers at the schools so designated as aforesaid not later than 8:55 o'clock in the forenoon of each school day and shall have the vehicle at the schools to take up the passengers at such times in the afternoon as shall be designated by the Department or its Agent in the afternoon of each school day.

5. When proceeding along the route the driver of the vehicle shall sound a distinctive warning by horn or otherwise when approaching any point at which any child or children is or are in the habit of entering the vehicle and shall use all proper and reasonable means to ensure the transportation to and from a school of all children so designated as aforesaid.

6. The Contractors shall comply with all and every the provisions of the Motor-Vehicle Act (Revised Statutes of British Columbia 1936 Chapter 195) and any amendments thereto now or hereafter in force and applicable and in particular shall comply with the said Regulations set forth in the said Order of the Lieutenant-Governor in Council and any other regulations and orders now or which may hereafter from time to time be in force and applicable.

7. The Contractors shall maintain a good safe efficient and punctual service and shall equip and operate all vehicles in such manner as will ensure the reasonable comfort and shelter of the passengers therein PROVIDED ALWAYS that the Contractors
shall not be bound to maintain the service upon any route during such time as it shall be rendered impassable or dangerous by reason of deep snow or other cause beyond the control of the Contractors but the Contractors shall not be entitled to any remuneration during such time.

8. The Contractors shall at the Contractors' own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in respect of each vehicle against public liability and against loss of life and injury to the children who may be passengers in any vehicle and any person carried therein accompanying or in charge of such children or any of them in an Insurance Company or Insurance Companies approved by the Department and such insurance shall cover the Contractors and all or any liability of the Department in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the claim of any one individual and in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one accident and in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for damage to property and the Contractors shall punctually pay all premiums in respect of such insurance and deliver the receipts for such premiums to the Department and produce the policies to the Department for inspection upon demand.

9. The Contractors shall also at the Contractors' own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in favour of the Department against non-owners liability in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for or in respect of any legal liability of the Department for bodily injury to or the death of any one person and subject to
such limit for any one person so injured or killed in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident and any policy for such insurance shall also extend to and cover all school children their attendants or teachers while being transported to or from school to or from games and to or from outings in the personal charge of the Department, or in a motor vehicle operated by the Contractors. The premiums for such insurance shall be paid by the Contractors and all and every policy for such insurance shall be in the name of the Department.

10. The Contractors shall employ as drivers of vehicles competent chauffeurs of good moral character and shall cease to employ any person as driver or assistant on any vehicle if so requested in writing by the Department.

11. The Contractors shall maintain the service solely for the transportation of children to and from school as aforesaid and no person other than the chauffeur or an employee of the Contractors' assistant to the chauffeur or any teacher or teachers in the employ of the Department shall be permitted to be on board any vehicle at any time while engaged in such service.

12. The remuneration to be paid by the Department to the Contractors for the service hereunder shall be calculated as follows:

The sum of thirty-five (35) cents per mile per day for all children up to the number of thirty (30) and for the purpose of calculating such remuneration the said route shall be deemed to measure thirty-two (32) miles inclusive of the inward and return trips twice a day, the Contractor to submit
his account for the service at the end of each month for payment, subject to any adjustment or correction by the Department.

THE CONTRACTORS shall transport any children over and above the number prescribed for any route if the vehicle in use has sufficient capacity therefor but shall not be entitled to any further remuneration for any children above the prescribed number so transported PROVIDED ALWAYS that in the event of the circumstances prescribed in the Schedule hereto taking place in respect of either of the said Routes the said remuneration may be varied from time to time upon notice in writing given by either party hereto to the other party and thereupon such variation shall take place as from the date of service of such notice calculated in accordance with provisions applicable as set forth in the said Schedule.

13. The service shall not be continued and the said remuneration shall not be payable during the usual school vacations nor shall the service be continued nor shall the remuneration be payable during any period other than the said vacations when the schools shall be closed.

14. The Department shall have power from time to time to change any route by any variation extension or modification thereof PROVIDED that in the event of any such extension the Department shall pay to the Contractor as remuneration an additional amount per mile or part of a mile by which the route is so extended calculated at the rate provided in Clause 12 hereof in respect of such route and in the event of any modification of a route the remuneration of the Contractors shall be reduced.
by an amount per mile or part of a mile by which the route is so modified calculated at the rate provided in Clause 12 hereof in respect of such route and in the event of any dispute as to the measurement of any such extension or modification such measurement shall be ascertained by a British Columbia Land Surveyor whose fees shall be paid as to one-half thereof by the Department and as to the remaining one-half thereof by the Contractors.

15. Subject to Clause 14 hereof it is agreed that in the event of any dispute difference or question arising between the said parties hereto out of the construction or carrying out of the terms of these presents the same shall be referred to Arbitration pursuant to the Arbitration Act.

16. 17. The Department shall have the option of cancelling this agreement at any time by ninety days notice to the Contractors by notice sent by registered mail addressed to him at Duncan, British Columbia.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am in receipt of Mr. Bethune's memorandum of March 18 with reference to the bus service to the Cowichan Indian Day School.

As I advised you in my memorandum of February 8 there is no serious objection to the Department entering into a contract for a longer period than the one originally considered.

Consequently the agreement forwarded by Mr. J. A. Kyle, Proprietor, Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Service, was submitted to the Departmental Solicitor, Mr. K. R. Daly. In memorandum dated February 22 he submitted certain changes which he considered should be made in the agreement. These proposed changes were forwarded to Indian Commissioner MacKay who discussed them with Mr. Kyle and in a letter dated February 29 Commissioner MacKay stated that Mr. Kyle was willing to accept the changes suggested by Mr. Daly. A new agreement was then prepared embodying the changes and was again submitted to Mr. Daly who, in a memorandum dated March 13, advised as follows:

"I have carefully gone over the new draft agreement in the light of the comments and explanations which have been made and I am of opinion that it is now satisfactory from the viewpoint of the Department and may properly be executed."
This new agreement has been forwarded to Indian Commissioner MacKay for the signature of Mr. Kyle. It has not yet been returned but in view of Mr. Kyle's previous decision to accept the amendments suggested I have no reason to doubt that he will sign it. Clause No. 1 of this agreement provides as follows:

"The Contractors shall inaugurate and maintain during the period commencing on the 1st day of January 1940 and terminating on the 30th day of June 1945 (both days being included in the period) a motor vehicle service for the purpose of conveying and shall convey in a motor vehicle or motor vehicles to and from such school or schools as the Department shall from time to time designate and notify to the Contractors within the boundaries of the Cowichan Indian Reserve such children as shall from time to time be designated by the Department or its Agent and notified by it to the Contractors."

MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT made this Nineteenth day of December in the year of our Lord One thousand nine hundred and thirty-nine BETWEEN: HIS MAJESTY THE KING IN THE RIGHT OF CANADA AS REPRESENTED BY THE DIRECTOR OF THE INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH OF THE DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES hereinafter called "the Department" of the one part and J. A. KYLE of the City of Duncan in the Province of British Columbia carrying on business as Cowichan Valley Bus and Taxi Services (Kyle) and HOWARD VALENTINE KYLE of the said City of Duncan (hereinafter called "the Contractors") of the other part.

WHEREAS the Department is required to provide for the transportation to and from school of certain school children

AND WHEREAS in the pursuance of such requirement the Department has entered into an arrangement with the Contractors for such means of transportation and these presents are for the purpose of setting out the terms and conditions of the agreement entered into by the parties hereto

NOW THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that it is agreed by and between the respective parties hereto the Contractors agreeing jointly and severally as follows:-

1. The Contractors shall inaugurate and maintain during the period commencing on the 1st day of January 1940 and terminating on the 30th day of June 1945 (both days being included in the period) a motor vehicle service for the purpose of conveying and shall convey in a motor vehicle or motor vehicles to and from such school or schools as the Department shall from time to time designate and notify to the Contractors within the boundaries of the Cowichan Indian Reserve such children as shall
from time to time be designated by the Department or its Agent and notified by it to the Contractors.

2. Subject to Section 21(d) of the Regulations under the "Motor-Vehicle Act" set forth in an Order of the Lieutenant-Governor in Council dated the 12th day of April 1935 each child shall be taken on board the vehicle on its way to the school and shall be permitted to alight on the return journey from the school at such points on the said route as may from time to time be designated by the Department.

3. The Contractors shall maintain the service along the following routes that is to say:

A.M. Leave the Somenos Indian village on the Cowichan Indian Reserve proceeding northerly along the Island Highway turning east on to the Trunk road and Victoria road to the new Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School, thence via the old Victoria road through the Cowichan Indian Reserve to the Island Highway, thence westerly along said highway to the Koksilah Mission road, thence north to Koksilah Mission near the Koksilah Indian School, thence returning over the same route to the said Consolidated Indian Day School.

P.M. Leave the said Consolidated Indian Day School and proceed via the old Victoria road and Cowichan Indian Reserve and the Island Highway, thence westerly to the Koksilah Mission road, thence north to Koksilah Mission near Koksilah Indian School, thence returning by the same route to said Consolidated Indian Day School, thence west to said Somenos Indian Village via the old Victoria road to the Island Highway as per plan attached.
4. The Contractors shall maintain such service on each and every school day during the currency of this agreement and shall so time the passage of the vehicle along the route reasonably so as to deliver and the Contractors shall deliver the passengers at the schools so designated as aforesaid not later than 8:55 o'clock in the forenoon of each school day and shall have the vehicle at the schools to take up the passengers at such times in the afternoon as shall be designated by the Department or its Agent in the afternoon of each school day and shall proceed forthwith to transport and shall transport each of them to his or her destination along the route.

5. When proceeding along the route the driver of the vehicle shall sound a distinctive warning by horn or otherwise when approaching any point at which any child or children is or are in the habit of entering the vehicle and shall use all proper and reasonable means to ensure the transportation to and from a school of all children so designated as aforesaid.

6. The Contractors shall comply with all and every the provisions of the Motor-Vehicle Act (Revised Statutes of British Columbia 1936 Chapter 125) and any amendments thereto now or hereafter in force and applicable and in particular shall comply with the said Regulations set forth in the said Order of the Lieutenant-Governor in Council and any other regulations and orders now or which may hereafter from time to time be in force and applicable.

7. The Contractors shall maintain a good safe efficient and punctual service and shall equip and operate all vehicles in such manner as will ensure the reasonable comfort and shelter of the passengers therein PROVIDED ALWAYS that the Contractors
shall not be bound to maintain the service upon any route during such time as it shall be rendered impassable or dangerous by reason of deep snow or other cause beyond the control of the Contractors but the Contractors shall not be entitled to any remuneration during such time.

8. The Contractors shall at the Contractors' own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in respect of each vehicle against public liability and against loss of life and injury to the children who may be passengers in any vehicle and any person carried therein accompanying or in charge of such children or any of them in an Insurance Company or Insurance Companies approved by the Department and such insurance shall cover the Contractors and all or any liability of the Department in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the claim of any one individual and in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one accident and in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for damage to property and the Contractors shall punctually pay all premiums in respect of such insurance and deliver the receipts for such premiums to the Department and produce the policies to the Department for inspection upon demand.

9. The Contractors shall also at the Contractors' own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in favour of the Department against non-owners liability in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for or in respect of any legal liability of the Department for bodily injury to or the death of any one person and subject to
such limit for any one person so injured or killed in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident and any policy for such insurance shall also extend to and cover all school children their attendants or teachers while being transported to or from school to or from games and to or from outings in the personal charge of the Department while in a motor vehicle operated by the Contractors. The premiums for such insurance shall be paid by the Contractors and all and every policy for such insurance shall be in the name of the Department.

10. The Contractors shall employ as drivers and assistants of vehicles competent chauffeurs of good moral character and at once shall cease to employ any person as driver or assistant on any vehicle if so requested in writing by the Department.

11. The Contractors shall maintain the service solely for the transportation of children to and from school as aforesaid and no person other than the chauffeur or an employee of the Contractors' assistant to the chauffeur or any teacher or teachers in the employ of the Department shall be permitted to be on board any vehicle at any time while engaged in such service.

12. The remuneration to be paid by the Department to the Contractors for the service hereunder shall be calculated as follows:

The sum of thirty-five (35) cents per mile per day for all children up to the number of thirty (30) and for the purpose of calculating such remuneration the said route shall be deemed to measure thirty-two (32) miles inclusive of the inward and return trips twice a day, the Contractor to submit
his account for the service at the end of each month for payment, subject to any adjustment or correction by the Department.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 1st instant with reference to payment of bus transportation for school children proceeding to the Ste. Catherine's School.

The Department is aware that the rate is 35¢ a mile when the number of pupils is 30 or over and 40¢ a mile when the number exceeds 30.

What arrangements have been made to check the number travelling in the bus? Apparently from the accounts received the firm is charging us for over 30 pupils every day. It was distinctly understood that pupils living within one mile of the Ste. Catherine's School would not be transported and consequently the Department requires very definite information regarding the method that has been adopted to make certain that the bus company will not overcharge us.

In future the monthly account should be accompanied by a statement signed by the Principal of the school showing the number of pupils brought to the school each day in the bus.

No promise was made by the Department for transportation of children to the Koksilah School. The agreement, as far as we were concerned, simply covers the Ste. Catherine's School. While we have no objection to children living over a mile from the Koksilah School being transported to that school if there is room in the bus, at the same time when preparing the voucher you should only mention the Ste. Catherine's School.

Mr. R. H. Moore,

I, therefore, find it necessary to return the accounts for the months of January, February and March. The account for the month of April has not yet reached us.

With regard to the January account why was the bus engaged for three days to transport children to the Koksilah School? We do not appear to have any record of having authorized this because, as stated above, the transportation by bus was arranged primarily for the children attending the Ste. Catherine's School and consequently the bus should not have been put in operation until this school was open. A new voucher should be prepared for the month of January and only the Ste. Catherine's School should be mentioned.

The February account appears in order provided that you consider that on each of the twenty-one days more than 30 pupils were transported. A new covering voucher, however, should be prepared for this as you should only mention the Ste. Catherine's School.

It is doubtful if the March account is correct. We are not paying on the average attendance but on the number actually transported each day. If the average for the fourteen days on which transportation was supplied during the month of March was only $31.13/14 it is quite likely that on some of the days at least the number transported was 30 or under and consequently for those days we are entitled to the 35¢ a mile rate.

When returning these accounts you should forward separate vouchers with the accounts attached for each month and you should, as suggested in the first part of this letter, attach a definite statement showing the number of pupils transported each school day.

Yours truly,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, which was in reply to mine of the 1st inst., relative to the transportation of the children to the St. Catherine's and Koksilah Indian Day Schools. I must admit that I am amazed at the apparent misunderstanding that has developed in connection with the transportation system, in spite of the fact that I have been sending complete and detailed reports in duplicate through the Indian Commissioner ever since last fall. In fact the first one was dated September 24th last and was in reply to Mr Hoey's letter of September 2nd, addressed to Major MacKay who sent me a copy of it asking for information, which I supplied by way of a long written report in duplicate, as well as letters in duplicate from two local Bus Firms which explained the route taken and which they were quoting on. In fact it was from those letters that the Department eventually decided to give the contract to Kyle.

Please understand that up until now nearly all correspondence has gone through the Commissioner from the Department, he in turn writing to me and I replying through him in duplicate. Only once or twice have I actually received copies of your letters to the Commissioner, he generally advised me that the Department wished to be informed on certain points to which I replied, and always in duplicate.

As soon as it was decided in Ottawa last December that Kyle should have the business, the Department asked that the term of the contract be increased to five years instead of six months as originally tendered on by Mr Kyle. That information was given to me over the telephone by the Indian Commissioner last December during the time that Inspector's Coleman and Barry were in this Office and Mr Kyle was asked to call at the office and discuss the whole situation with Inspector Coleman, which he did, the result of that consultation being the Agreement which was drawn up and forwarded to the Department for approval. I might say that this Agreement was signed by the Company and forwarded by me to the Commissioner in duplicate under date of November 22nd, last. Nothing further was heard of it until February 1st, when the Commissioner wrote me stating that the Department did not consider it advisable to sign the Contract at that time but wished to carry on as heretofore, which to me was hard to understand as there had been no heretofore with this Company. At all events I notified the Company of this under date of February 2nd. The on February 27th, the Commissioner wrote me point out that the Contract had been reviewed by the Senior Solicitor of the Department when certain small changes were suggested, and I was again instructed to interview Mr Kyle and discuss the proposed changes.

The above is a detailed report of the whole affair up to now insofar as I have connected with it. From here on I will confine myself to replying to and explaining the various points mentioned in your letter.

Re, the third paragraph of your letter: No pupils within a radius of one mile is being carried on the Bus, that is within a radius of one mile of the School, of course. The driver of the Bus keeps a daily record of the children carried one way to the School, as well as the total number carried each day. At the end of each month the original statement is turned in by the Company attached to their monthly accounts, this statement is kept on our copy of the Voucher in this Office. I can assure you that no attempt is being made by the Bus Company to overcharge us.

Re, fourth paragraph of your letter: It would appear as if the Department is not fully aware of the geography of the Cowichan I. R., of how the transportation of the children is being handled, or of the route taken, otherwise you would readily see that when the Bus leave the Somonos Indian Village in the morning that it has a full load of children sometimes as high as 50, half of which unload at St. Catherine's School, the balance staying in the Village proceeding on through the Reserve until the end of the trip where they get off and walk the rest of the way to the Koksilah School. There the bus turns round, and returns back to the St. Catherine's School picking up the children en route. You will see from this therefore that on the first trip to the St. Catherine's school only about one third of the pupils in the bus actually get on the school bus during the Koksilah School, in other words the load is divided between the two schools so that it would hardly be fair to ask any of the teachers to certify that a certain number of children were in the Bus at one time or on one trip. However, there is certainly no reason why the Principal of St. Catherines' School cannot keep a record of the total number of children carried each day by the Bus, if the Department so desires, and I will ask her to do that as from this date.

Re, fifth paragraph of your letter: The statement you make in this paragraph is hard to understand, especially in view of the fact that we have been paying for the transportation of the children attending the Koksilah School since long before I came to this Agency. However, if you so desire, the Koksilah School will not appear on the Voucher in future.

Re: sixth paragraph of your letter: Newly made out Vouchers are being submitted herewith covering the months of January, February, March and April, which will show in detail the exact number of pupils carried each day on the Bus and the rate charged. This method will, I hope, give you all the information you desire.

Re: seventh paragraph: The reason the Bus was engaged for the first three days to carry pupils to the Koksilah School, was because the School was open and the St. Catherine's school was not owing to the fact that it was not ready, being entirely without equipment of any kind, and as there had been transportation facilities provided for the children of the Koksilah School prior to the opening of the St. Catherine's school, I saw no reason why this service should be discontinued without definite instructions from the Department. As I understand the situation the Bus service is not a venture but rather a change over to a larger Bus than the car previously used for this work by the Rev. Father L. LeClair, and which he used to carry the children to both the Old Cowichan Day School and the Koksilah Day School. However, as stated above a new Voucher will be submitted for January and the Koksilah school will not be mentioned although we are in duty bound to pay for the transportation of the children taken to the Koksilah School on January 3rd, 4th, and 5th.

In reading your letter carefully I cannot but feel some concern about the attitude of the Department towards the Koksilah School, which to my mind does not appear to be favourable and I wish to be perfectly frank and outspoken in the matter now so that no misunderstanding may arise later through lack of any definite statement on our part on the subject of this School. To my mind the Koksilah School is the best managed and best run school in the Agency, and I feel that I am safe in saying that the pupils there are deriving more actual benefit from their schooling than any any of the pupils attending any of our other schools. I make that statement believing it to be true, and I think that it would be a calamity were the services rendered this School by the Department over a period of years now curtailed by cutting out or curtailing the transportation service.

In view of the apparent ignorance of the Department as to just what route the Bus takes and how the Cowichan I. R. is served by the Bus service, I am sending you a Blueprint of the Reserve, with the Route marked in Red, which will show the point at which the Bus leaves in the morning and the measured distances between the various points. However, this is the only Map I have of this Reserve in this office and so I am asking you to be kind enough to return it as soon as you have finished with it. If there happens to be anyone out in this Province this year from Head Office I would like him to visit me here so that I could actually take him over the route travelled. In the meantime I hope that the blueprint will suffice. Sorry to trouble with such a long-winded report but I feel that I ought to cover the whole question in detail and my only concern is that this report will be understandable.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant there was never any intention on the part of the Department to prohibit the children of the Koksilah School using the bus. In this connection I would refer you to the fifth paragraph of my letter of May 4 addressed to Indian Agent Moore and a copy of which was sent to you on the same day. It was simply that we wanted the vouchers to read "Ste. Catherine's Day School".

The copy of the agreement forwarded to you should be sent to the Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Company. We have retained a copy on file here.

The accounts have been re-submitted to us and have been prepared on the basis of the number of pupils carried each day and not on the average over a given period. This is the correct procedure and a cheque in payment of the months of January, February, March and April has gone forward.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
Dear Sir:

Your File 152-22-5.

I have to refer to your letter of May 4th enclosing copy of agreement with J.A. Kyle in connection with the transportation of children to the Ste. Catherine's School. As Inspector Barry is not due to return from the north until mid-June, I took advantage of the opportunity on Friday last, while in Duncan to discuss the subject matter of your letter with Mr. Indian Agent Moore.

Although there is no mention in the agreement of the Koksilah Indian Day School, I am satisfied that it was the intention to include those pupils of that school living over a mile from the school in the group to be transported by the Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Services. I am sure the Department will not approve for obvious reasons of our Protestant school children walking to school while Roman Catholic children on the same route were being transported by bus under Departmental arrangements.

There should be no need to include any reference on the voucher to the Koksilah School. It will be necessary, however, to secure from the Rev. Principal of Ste. Catherine's and Miss Perry, of the Koksilah School, a certificate showing the number of pupils carried by the bus each day to their respective schools; otherwise I cannot see how a satisfactory check can be obtained. It was understood from the outset that payment would be made on the basis of the number of pupils carried each day and not on the average over a given period, and the accounts are to be submitted accordingly.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I...
I should appreciate being advised if the copy of the agreement forwarded to me is for the Agency records, the Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Company or to be returned to the Department.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay.

Ottawa, August 29, 1940.

Re: Ste. Catherine's Consolidated Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 16th instant, in which you seek departmental authority to proceed with certain improvements to the grounds surrounding the above noted school.

I find it exceedingly difficult to even suggest what should be done to the grounds of this school, in view of the engineer's recommendations, the limited funds at our disposal and the difficulty experienced last year by the members of the staff when the pupils were continually carrying clay on their boots into the classrooms.

It is, as you know, comparatively easy to be wise after the event, and I am convinced that in future, when an Indian day school is constructed, it should be constructed on the understanding that the contractors will not only construct the school but will provide the lavatories that may be necessary, the fence surrounding the grounds and any improvements required to the grounds. I feel it is somewhat misleading to inform the Minister of Parliament that a certain school has cost so much and then be compelled to spend approximately $1,000 the next year in the improvement of the grounds surrounding the same school.

In the estimates of this year the sum of $580 was set apart for the repair of Indian day schools in the Cowichan agency. Of this amount approximately $282 has been spent to date. You can readily appreciate, therefore, that the funds at our disposal are scarcely sufficient to even make start on the work outlined by the engineer, in connection with the Ste. Catherine's School. I have been wondering if it would be possible to spend the sum of approximately $500.00 on the improvements that may be absolutely necessary. I have in mind the sidewalks, drainage, etc., and in regard to the fence recommended by the engineer I have

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.
been wondering if it would be possible to have this constructed by Indian labour, under the direction of the manual training instructor. In any event, it is simply unthinkable that we should spend a sum exceeding $500 on the Ste. Catherine's School this year, in view of the fact that we have been unable to open a large number of Indian schools in the outlying districts of the Dominion.

I should like to have any comments you may care to offer on these suggestions. In the meantime I agree with you that the work should be undertaken at once and you should so advise the Agent.

I am anxious to know if you have a copy of Mr. Whyte's report.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of August 22nd, your file 152-22-5, regarding the improvements recommended to the grounds of the marginally noted school.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter above noted with reference to the application of Mr. P. J. Corcoran to be allowed to drive the School Bus which takes the Indian children and from the Indian Day Schools on the Cowichan I. R.

Your objections mentioned in the second paragraph of your letter are noted, but I would point out that the very fact that Mr. Corcoran is operating the Bus means that he would have the children under Supervision one hour longer each day than if someone else did it. The Bus would be kept at the School all day so that from the time the children arrived, and until they left, Mr. Corcoran would be there.

Your statement in the third paragraph is not quite correct as you will please note if you refer to Dept. Circular Letter of April 24th, 1939 #710-871 which states that unless the employee is receiving salary in excess of $1200.00 annually this ruling would not apply. Furthermore, it is very doubtful whether or not this man could be termed a full time employee, in the broad sense of the word, as he is only employed by this Department two thirds of a year and his salary amounts to $760.00.

There is no question of Mr. Corcoran resigning to accept Mr. Kyle's offer. The plan suggested of this man driving our Bus, or at least the bus which we hire, is (to my mind at least) a good one and one which I would ask be reconsidered. If you will please refer to previous correspondence in connection with the Bus service I think you will find that when it was suggested that we operate our own bus one of the arguments in favor of it was the additional interest which the driver, who by the way was also going to be the Manual Training Instructor? would take in seeing that the children came regularly to School.

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Vancouver, B. C.

Yours obediently,

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.
Indian Commissioner's Office,
Vancouver, B.C., Sept. 23, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 21st instant with which you forward and recommend an application from Mr. P. J. Corcoran that he be permitted to operate for Mr. Kyle the St. Catherine's and Koksilah School bus service.

I would draw your attention to the fact that Mr. Corcoran is now being paid by the Department for his work as Boys' Supervisor and Manual Training Instructor on a whole-time basis on the assumption that his work involves full-time employment. It would appear obvious that if Mr. Corcoran is operating a school bus away from St. Catherine's he could not at the same time take proper charge of the boys at that school.

It is hardly necessary to remind you that full-time Departmental employees are prohibited from receiving compensation for work from outside sources.

I regret that it is quite impossible for me to recommend to the Department that Mr. Corcoran's application be favorably considered. Should he desire to accept Mr. Kyle's offer, it will be necessary for him first to resign his position as Boys' Supervisor and Manual Training Instructor at St. Catherine's School.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. Mackay.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
