Memorandum to Mr. Webb,

Re: Heating and Water Supply Systems at St. Catherine's School,
Vancouver, B.C.

Sir:

Further to my memorandum to you dated October 5th, 1940 with reference to complaints about the heating and water supply systems at the above mentioned school, I now submit a final report on these matters.

The complaints as given to me verbally by Mr. Indian Agent Moore and outlined in his letter dated September 15th, 1940 to D. M. MacKay, Esq., Indian Commissioner for British Columbia were:

1. The drinking water has a most disagreeable odour.
2. The heating system fails to heat the building adequately.

Heating System:

I revisited the school on November 28th, 1940 and found that the heating system was functioning satisfactorily as the Indian Janitor now appears to have grasped the correct ideas of the manipulation of the hot air distributing controls.

I would strongly recommend that an automatic door closer be attached to one door of both the
front and rear entrances as it is difficult to keep these doors closed in a school. Mr. Indian Agent Moore suggested that the door closers could be installed by the manual-training teacher. The two door closers of the Corbin type No. 3 can be supplied at the school for $12.00 each, a total of $26.00 complete. These were not provided for in the building specifications of this school.

Water Supply System.

As was noted in my previous memorandum, this well was dug in July, 1939, and was deepened, cribbed, capped and had an electric pumping unit installed in December of that year. The water subsequently developed a disagreeable taste and odour in the spring of 1940 and this condition was intensified during the summer when the well was not in use. Such was the condition of the water on my visit of September 26th, 1940, but on the following day, the well having been pumped out in the interval, the water, which had accumulated, was found to have the same flat mineral taste, but practically no odour. Inside the well the disagreeable odour remained, the venting originally provided being insufficient as there was no indication or local experience to indicate such a condition of gaseous evolution arising.

A bacteriological test of the water, dated October 11th, 1940 made by the Provincial Board of Health shows the water to be free of faecal bacteria and therefore indicates that there is no pollution. A copy of this report is attached.
A chemical analysis of the water was obtained through the Sanitary Inspector's Office of the Provincial Board of Health and done by the Provincial Department of Mines.

Attached is a copy of the Chief Sanitary Inspector's letter dated November 28th, 1940 interpreting the results of the chemical analysis, dated November 18th, 1940, a copy of which is also attached.

It will be noted that the Chief Sanitary Inspector states that the water appears to be of good quality, and the figure of total solids, 12.6 grains per gallon is not excessive, that the water would be classed as hard, but is not harmful to the health. Further he notes that while the sulphur content of the water is nil, the description of the well indicates there is probably H2S present in the water at the well, but as this gas passes off rapidly in the presence of the atmosphere it would not be present in the sample reaching the laboratory and hence by the time the water is used for drinking purposes, the smell of H2S is gone, it is not harmful to health.

In view of the foregoing reports, both bacteriological and chemical, it is safe to say that this well water is satisfactory for human consumption.

However, as the well has a disagreeable odour and there will be a continued evolution of H2S gas, the following suggestion should prove a simple and inexpensive
way to ventilate the well, if it is desired to do so. That a 4-foot by 4-foot structure 6 feet high, with open cable ends be built over the existing trap-door in the present well cover and bolted down to the cover in order that it may be removed should the cover have to be raised to allow maintenance work to be performed on the electrical pumping unit.

It is necessary to raise any such ventilation opening above the reach of the children, otherwise extraneous matter will be getting into the well. A fence would prove ineffective. The present hatch would be left open, but would remain attached so that in cold weather it could be closed if freezing-up of the pumping unit is feared.

The cost of materials for this structure is estimated at $25.00 and according to Mr. Indian Agent Moore could be erected by the manual-trainer. Should Indian labour be employed to erect the structure the cost of such labour would be $15.00. A suggested plan of the structure is attached.

Your obedient servant,

H. T. Ramsden.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed a copy of the Chief Analyst's report on the sample of water from the Indian School at Duncan.

This water appears to be of good quality due to this report and the former bacteriological reports. The figure for total solids is not excessive. Most of the solids is made up of calcium bicarbonate, which is also known as temporary hardness. This causes the formation of deposits and may cause a white precipitate (calcium carbonate) in the kettle. It may also cause a milky appearance at times. This is not harmful to health, although it would be classed as a hard water.

The Na Cl and K Cl is about the usual for well waters.

The sulphur content is nil, but from a description of the well, there probably is H2S (hydrogen sulphide) present in the water at the well. However, this gas passes off rapidly in the presence of the atmosphere, and it would not be present when the sample reached the laboratory. The hydrogen sulphide is probably due to decomposing vegetation in the swampy land near Duncan.

Since, by the time the water is used for drinking purposes, the smell of the hydrogen sulphide is gone, it is not harmful to health.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Cowichan Indian Day School, Duncan, B.C.

Herewith is a report, in duplicate, covering the inspection by Engineer Ramsden of the heating system and water supply at the above school.

You will observe that since the Indian caretaker has been instructed on the proper operation of the heating plant, it is functioning satisfactorily.

With regard to the water supply system, Mr. Ramsden reports that after bacteriological and chemical analyses by the Provincial Board of Health, the water has been found to be free from pollution. It would be classed as hard but is satisfactory for human consumption. It appears, however, that the water contains a trace of H2S (Hydrogen sulphide) which, in the covered well, creates an unpleasant odor. To lessen this odor Mr. Ramsden recommends the erection of an inexpensive ventilating structure over the top of the well with openings within the reach of the school children, as indicated on the sketch accompanying the report. The existing covering would be retained, and except when danger or freezing existed, the trap door would remain open. The estimated cost of materials for this structure is approximately $25.00.

Mr. Ramsden has also recommended the installation of two door closers, one for each entrance to the school. These were not included in the contract for the erection of the school, and are estimated to cost $13.00 each.

It is understood that both the well ventilating structure and the door closers could be installed by the manual training instructor at the school, without expense to the Department, thus restricting the total necessary expenditure to $38.00.

Mr. Ramsden's suggestions are considered essential, and the cost is reasonable. It is recommended, therefore, that the Indian Affairs Branch be advised that the work should be undertaken as soon as possible under the supervision of the Indian Agent at Duncan, B.C., and utilizing the services of the manual training instructor at the school.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,

January 17, 1941.

Mr. R.H. Moore, Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.

Dear Mr. Moore:

It is my duty to inform you that this morning an accident occurred to one of the boys of the Primary Class, Roy Harry. As Mr. George May, the Bus driver, took on one of the school children, Roy, who sat in the front seat, unthinkingly placed his fingers right in the door. Not noticing this, the driver slammed the door, catching the index finger of Roy's right hand. Immediately upon his arrival at the school, Mr. Pat Corcoran brought the boy in Chris Camute's car to the Doctor who decided to amputate the first joint of the finger. Thereupon Roy was taken to the Hospital where he is at present.

From information gathered from the children who witnessed the accident, the driver is not at fault. Roy is a subnormal boy, who acts heedlessly without regard to consequences.

This mishap gives rise to the occasion of mentioning the risk taken by Mr. Kyle of continuing to run the school bus when it is no longer fit for the service intended. It is too small for the accommodation of the present pupilage of St. Catherine's School. Four or five children must daily sit in a seat conveniently large enough for two only. On three different occasions the bus broke down which forced them to walk to school twice and once they arrived at 9:15.

Your immediate attention to this matter would be much appreciated by all concerned.

Very sincerely yours,

"Sister Mary Armella"
Principal.
Duncan, B. C.

January 20th, 1941.

D. M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
P. O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a letter just received this morning from Sister Mary Armella, Principal of the St. Catherine's School, relating to an accident which occurred to one of the pupils on the school bus last Friday morning which I trust you will find in order.

I might say that this accident was reported to me within an hour after it occurred by Mr. Kyle, who explained that it was purely an accident and that it was impossible for the driver to notice the boy's hand being in the back of the door at the time it was being closed. I can quite understand this as a finger can be put in so quickly that it would be next to impossible to even expect any driver to see it.

With regard to the Principal's complaint that the bus is no longer suitable for the services intended, I might say that this is hardly correct otherwise a license would not be issued by the Police Department. As you will remember 35 to 40 pupils is all that the bus was engaged for but some days there are actually more than 40 pupils riding in it, which makes it rather crowded. However, Mr. Kyle informed me that his new bus should have been here at the beginning of the current school term, but that owing to difficulties in delivery it has not yet arrived from Seattle where it is being assembled, although it is expected daily.

It is quite true that the present bus broke down on three different occasions this term, but none of these breakages were of a serious nature and as a matter of fact, two of them were directly responsible to the poor condition of the road through part of the Reserve over which the bus has got to travel. In any case, the new bus may be in operation any day now which should relieve this situation. I might mention that the boy was out of hospital within a few hours after having had his finger amputated at the first joint. To my mind it was purely an unfortunate accident without blame to anyone.

Yours obediently,

(R. H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

February 5, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith a file of correspondence with reference to the transportation of the pupils of St. Catherine's Indian Day School in the Cowichan Agency by the Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Service (Kyle).

The Reverend Principal's letter of the 17th ultimo reported that a pupil, Roy Harry David, had been injured in the bus, resulting in the amputation of a finger at the first joint, that the bus in use at that time was unfit for this service and subject to breakdowns, and was overcrowded. My letter of the 24th ultimo to Mr. Indian Agent Moore suggested that this boy should be compensated by the Company for injury and that they should pay any medical costs that would be a charge against this Department. Mr. Moore replied on the 27th ultimo that another bus had been put on this service and that he did not feel like making a claim against the Company.

It would appear from this correspondence that the service rendered by this Company for the conveyance of these children did not meet our requirements. Road conditions alone could hardly account for breakdowns and, on one occasion, loss of a wheel, the country being comparatively level and free of snow. In any case, the condition of the road does not enter into the matter insofar as the provisions of the contract are concerned.

The bus now placed on this run is that taken off the service for the Duncan School Trustees and has more accommodation, but it remains to be seen whether or not it will meet our requirements. I am of the opinion that Mr. Moore should keep in close touch with the service rendered and if there are further breakdowns or accidents the continuation of this contract should receive careful consideration and Mr. Moore so advised.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Regarding the accident to the child, involving partial loss of a finger, the overcrowded condition of the bus would appear to be a contributory factor to this accident and I would appreciate advice as to whether a claim should be entered against the Company and, if the Department has any information on the subject, the usual rate of compensation paid in such cases.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter, date and file number above noted, in further reference to the recent accident to Roy Harry David son of the late Harry David of the Quamichan Band Cowichan I. R. #1, and Julia Jack of the Penelakut Band. Father has been dead for approximately six years and the mother deserted the boy about the same time and since then he has been cared for by his aunt, Mary K. Nechel of the Koksilah Band Cowichan I. R. #1.

The total Hospital charges in connection with the accident amounts to $1.00 and he was only in the hospital for a few hours before being sent home.

It is quite true that another bus has been put in service on this run but it is not the new one but one of the other buses used by this Company on the Public School run here until recently. So far as I am aware it is the intention of the operator to keep this bus on our school run indefinitely. It is certainly not his intention to use the new bus, and I don't blame him as the road is not suitable.

I might mention that this bus broke a wheel the second day it was on the run, and if you could drive over part of the road which it has to travel you would understand why the breakages occur, in spite of the fact that it is level country. I might also state that the new bus has arrived and is being used on the Public School run to replace the one which is being used at present on our run.

Yours obediently,

D. M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Vancouver, B. C.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 27th instant with reference to St. Catherine's School bus, I would request that you advise me, in duplicate, of the cost of hospitalization of the injured boy (whose name has not been given), and if he has been discharged from hospital.

It is noted in the last paragraph of your letter that another bus has been put in service in this connection and I would like to be advised whether or not this bus is to be kept on this run or if it is merely a temporary one until the new bus arrives, as set out in your letter of the 20th instant.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter, date and file number above noted, with reference to a report from the Rev. Principal attached to my letter of Jan. 20th regarding an accident to one of the pupils of St. Catherine's School while travelling on the school bus.

In few of the fact that the child who was injured is regarded as being sub-normal, I do not feel like making a claim against the Company unless definitely instructed by you so to do. No complaint has been made to me by the parents of the child since the accident occurred.

Regarding the last paragraph of your letter, I am not in a position to state why the bus breaks down but I do say that if the bus was not in reasonably good repair the Police Department would not give a permit for its operation. To explain break downs is difficult especially when I am not the driver and have got to depend on what I am told by other people.

For your information I wish to say that another bus has been put in service this morning on this school run. While it is not a new bus nevertheless it is in good repair and has been used on one of the white school bus routes; furthermore it will handle between 45 and 50 children without over-crowding.

Yours obediently,

(R. H. Moore)
Indian Agent.
January 24, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 20th instant with reference to your report of the Principal of St. Catherine's School regarding an accident which occurred to one of the pupils being conveyed by the school bus on the 17th instant, I would point out that Section 8 of the contract with the Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Service, dated December 19, 1939, makes the Company responsible for any injury to children who may be passengers in such vehicle. It appears to me that you could make claim against them on behalf of the child for compensation and also for any hospitalization or other medical expenses incurred outside of that given by the Medical Officer for the Reserve.

It is not understood why the bus, if it is in reasonable repair, should break down on comparatively level roads in the vicinity of Duncan notwithstanding the poor condition of the roads at the time. You should see that the Company provides proper transportation for these children and if they refuse to do so report to this office in order that the Department may review the matter of continuation of the Contract.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

R.M. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith in duplicate a letter from the Principal of the St. Catherine's School which I trust you will find self explanatory.

Not knowing the policy of the Department in regards to the supplying of musical instruments for the use of Day Schools in other parts of Canada, I would respectfully point out that St. Catherine's is a four roomed consolidated school where everything that is taught in a residential school practically, is taught there, so that to all intents and purposes there is very little difference in the actual educational facilities—in fact I personally feel that St. Catherine's is the better of the two.

Having this in mind, I assume that the teaching of music in the schools where the attendance warrants it, and suitable facilities exist, is encouraged by the Department but to what extent I naturally don't know. I would therefore respectfully request that I be informed if the Department would be good enough to consider purchasing a piano for the use of this School.

I note that the Principal asks for a second hand piano and I may say that if favourable consideration can be given to the request, I know of a splendid instrument which cost $500.00 about two years ago and which is in excellent condition, in a private home all the time and well cared for, which can be purchased now for $250.00 as the lady who owns it plans on moving into an apartment and has not got the room for it.

Yours obediently,

The Secretary;
Indian Affairs Branch,
Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

(R.H. Moore)

Mr. R. H. Moore, Indian Agent,

Dear Mr. Moore:

Since the opening of St. Catherine's School, January 1939, Sister Superior from St. Ann's School, Duncan, has, gratuitously, lent us an organ for the vocal education of our Indian charges. It was found necessary to remove the organ, leaving the school without a musical instrument, so much needed for the general development of the children. Voice culture has formed an important part in their training, and their response has been most gratifying.

What a pity for the pupils and a drawback for the school, were we obliged, owing to the absence of a musical instrument, to discontinue voice and dramatic training?

We would urge you, therefore, to kindly request a piano from the Department of Indian Affairs for St. Catherine's School. A second-hand instrument will be quite satisfactory.

Trusting to receive a favorable reply,

Very sincerely yours,

Sister Mary Amella,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

Re: St. Catherine's Indian Day School

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your air mail letter of September 15 and to state that you are authorized to instruct Indian Agent Moore to expend a sum not exceeding $40.00 for the repairs necessary at the above-noted school.

It would be deeply appreciated if the requests for these and other repairs at Indian day and residential schools in the Province of British Columbia reached us toward the close of each academic year. If requests for regular repairs reached us at that time I am of the opinion that a great deal of correspondence, particularly air mail correspondence, would be unnecessary. In any event it seems to me sound policy to insist that all repairs at our schools should be undertaken during the months of July and August if at all possible. It is my earnest hope that our Indian Agents will co-operate with us next year in the attempt we intend to make to have our repair programme started early in the season.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a Voucher amounting to £7.44 in favour of Hattie's Hardware, Duncan, B.C., for tools supplied some time ago to the St. Catherine Indian Day School.

In explanation of this expenditure I wish to point out that at the time the St. Catherine School was opened -- January, 1940--the new desks were delivered and had to be put on wooden runners which could be laid on the floor, this was to prevent the necessity of fastening the desks to the floor proper. It was found at that time that we did not have a suitable tool for this work and as the tools for the Manual Training Department had not been received it was necessary that this drill with bits be procured and later included in the requisition for the tools. Sir:

I beg to apply herewith for the usual grants for the Indian Day Schools in this Agency for the Cocoa and hot drinks for the children during the noon hour.

St Catherine's Indian Day School. $10.00 per school month.
Koksilah Indian Day School. 3.00 " "
Tsartlip Indian Day School, already applied for.

The considered opinion of the teachers of all the schools, and my own as well, is that this hot drink in the middle of the day is really a god-send to most of the children who bring their lunch to school, as oftentimes their lunch consists of bread and jam and the odd apple. Funnily enough it is the children who come from the poorer homes who are the most regular attendants at school and I believe in giving them every encouragement. In fact I believe that the hot drinks are responsible to a large extent for the lack of colds and minor sickness among the children and surely an ounce of prevention is better than a pound of cure.

I honestly believe that during the five or six months in the fall and winter that the Department would be well advised to arrange to have the teacher in the Day Schools serve hot soup each day at noon to those children who don't go home for lunch. It would not mean a large expenditure, about an average of $5.00 per month per school for soup bones, (and the children could bring the vegetables for it) but what a blessing to the children it would be as well as an excellent tonic of the kind that the Indian child does not get enough of.

If you would be good enough to give me the necessary authority to get the cocoa etc. as requested above, I would be greatly obliged.

The Secretary:

Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Re Transportation, St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

I am enclosing herewith a letter received from Mr. Indian Agent Moore recommending that permission be granted to Mr. P. Corcoran, employed as Boys' Supervisor and Manual Training instructor at St. Catherine's Indian Day School, to drive the bus used in transportation of children attending this school until such time as the Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Service can secure the services of a regular driver for this purpose.

It will be recalled that this question of the part-time employment of Mr. Corcoran as bus driver for this Company was before the Department last year and on that occasion the application was not approved. My objection to this proposal, even as a temporary measure, is that such an arrangement places a responsibility on the Department which, in view of the existing contract, should not be assumed. As pointed out previously, Mr. Corcoran is an employee of the Government and would, in my opinion, involve the Department if he were to take on the additional duties suggested. For this, and other reasons, I am not prepared to recommend the application. The Cowichan Valley Bus & Taxi Service should not depend on employees of this Department to assist them to the extent suggested to carry out the terms of their contract.

The suggestion that the morning sessions begin at ten o'clock does not meet with the Inspector's approval as the change would probably result in a decrease in attendance.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir:

Re: Bus Transportation for Day Schools on Cowichan I.R.

Mr. J.A. Kyle has approached me in regard to the possibility of our Manual Training Instructor at the St. Catherine's School being permitted to drive the School Bus on account of the shortage of Class A drivers, most of whom are in the Armed Forces.

This matter has been referred to the Department on a previous occasion but Ottawa did not consider it advisable to give the necessary permission. However, at that time the shortage of "Class A" men was not acute but it certainly is now and I am given to understand that the same condition exists all over this Island—viz., the impossibility to get qualified drivers.

Under the circumstances I would recommend that the Department be again approached on this matter with a view to getting them to permit Mr. Corcoran to drive the School Bus owing to unusual circumstances, as described above.

The only other alternative is that the Schools do not open until 10 a.m., so that the pupils can be handled in the Bus after it returns from the local public and high schools. The only objection to that is the lateness of the hour that the School would get out which would mean that it would be dark before the children go home and the light in some of the schools would be very poor for the last half hour of school, i.e., from 3:30 until 4:00 p.m.

Your early consideration to this matter will be appreciated, and it is understood that the above arrangement only lasts until Mr. Kyle can get a full time driver, with the necessary qualifications.

Yours obediently,

Major D.M. MacKey,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

During a recent visit to St. Catherine's Indian School, Cowichan Agency, the Reverend Principal called my attention to the need of a hot water tank and the necessary equipment to provide sufficient hot water for use at the School. At present water has to be heated in kettles on the stove and a small reservoir attached to the stove, which by no means provide the ordinary requirements of the School.

There is no doubt as to the real need for proper facilities for heating water for a school the size of St. Catherine's for use in the kitchen, for keeping the floors and woodwork cleaned, and by the pupils, and I would strongly recommend that the purchase of the necessary equipment be authorized. The cost of materials, including a new hot water jacket for the stove, would be approximately $49.00. The installation can be carried out by the Manual Training Instructor without cost to the Department.

An early reply in connection with this matter would be appreciated.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

CANADA
SIR:-

I beg to report having visited St. Catherine's Consolidated Indian Day School at Duncan, B.C., Cowichan Agency, for the purpose of making a tuberculosis survey of the pupils attending that School. The children attending the Cowichan Indian Day School, who reacted positively to the skin test were brought to St. Catherine's School for plating.

During the course of my visit to St. Catherine's School, I noted that no drinking fountains have as yet been installed either in the School building or outside adjacent to the play grounds.

In my opinion when possible the "common drinking cups" should be replaced by drinking fountains to avoid the direct transfer of infection from one or more unsuspected open cases of tuberculosis to children who have not as yet contracted the disease.

During the time I was in this School, I saw six or eight children line up at the top and drink one after the other, from a common drinking cup.

The drinking water at St. Catherine's School is pumped from a well by an automatic pump, so that there would be no difficulty in obtaining the required water pressure to operate drinking fountains.

I would recommend that two drinking fountains be installed within the school building, one in the common play room, and the other in the manual training room. A third fountain should be installed outside at a convenient point adjacent to the play grounds.

Your obedient servant,

A.L. McQuarrie, M.D.
Assistant Superintendent of Medical Services, B.C.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 31st ultimo, you may authorize the cleaning of the chimneys and pipes at the Koksihlah, Nanaimo Songhees, Tsartlip and St. Catherine's Indian Day Schools. Yours truly,

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith application dated the 28th instant received from Mr. Indian Agent Moore requesting authority to expend $32.00 for the cleaning of chimneys and pipes of the various Indian Day and Residential Schools in his Agency.

It is considered that the cleaning of the Kuper Island Residential School chimneys should be the duty of the school management and unless the Department has some reason for ruling otherwise, I am not prepared to recommend same. The cleaning of the chimneys of the other schools might be undertaken although it is felt the janitor of St. Catherine's Indian Day School should be able to reduce the cost some by cleaning the pipes. He would not have the equipment for cleaning the rather high brick chimneys.

Your advice will be appreciated.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Mr. R. H. Moore,

Re: Heating at St. Catherine's Indian Day School

Dear Sir:

As requested by you some time ago we have made a survey of the Hot Air Heating as installed at the above school and set out below some of our observations.

A. The furnace is a No.229 Good Cheer made by Clare Bros. It has a 28" diam. fire pot and is rated by this firm at 60,000 cubic feet heating capacity.

B. There is four class rooms each being supplied by a 22" diameter Hot air pipe having a 12" branch taken off in basement to heat the two lunch rooms and manual training shop. Each of the four class rooms have one 12" x 24" Hot Air opening and one 12" x 18" Return Air grill. From practical experience this is not a good set up for a gravity Hot Air heating system, particularly considering the position in which each has been placed.

C. At the time this school was being figured, we were asked to put in a tender for the heating. We were not satisfied with the plans and specifications then submitted and could not see our way clear to give the guarantee asked for on the proposed gravity system, we did however, submit plans, specification and a price on a forced air circulating system and were advised that it could not be considered by the department at that time.

D. We are of the opinion that if the hot air pipes are fitted with adjustable dampers and that the return air ducts are connected to a 15" fan properly housed and fitted to the furnace you can make the present system efficiently heat each class room to an even temperature, if properly operated. The heating of the lower rooms would possibly be sufficient but we could not say that they would in the coldest weather reach a high temperature.
E. We are pleased to recommend that a 155 Chinook 15" fan or equal be installed including Housing of same and making all return air duct and furnace connections, electrical work for Furnacestal to control operation of the fan, at a cost of $330.00

The installing of a fan on this job will greatly add to the life of the furnace.

F. We particularly draw to your attention that there is no provision for heat in the main Hallways and that the only heat they will get is from the Furnace room by opening the Furnace room door, which practice would not meet with the approval of the firemarshall.

Respectfully submitted,

ORMOND & GRIFFITHS

I beg to report that the Rev Principal of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School has reported to me that the electric iron at the school has gone out of commission owing to a thermostat in the mechanism going out of business. I spoke to the local electrician and he told me that this was the trouble and that it would cost approximately $3.50 for a new thermostat and about $1.50 for labor, or a total of $5.00 to put it back in working order again.

In discussing the matter with the Rev. Sister I wanted to know why it was necessary to have an automatic iron when the ordinary housewife got along with the customary electric iron without any automatic cut-off, and she stated that on account of several children using the same iron at several different times during the course of a day, there was always the chance that one or other of them would leave it on when they were finished with it and do serious damage; and that was the reason why the automatic type was purchased.

May I have your authority to have this iron repaired if-and when-a thermostat can be procured?

(R.H. Moore)

October 15, 1943.

MEMORANDUM TO MR. HERR:

Re: Cowichan Bay School
Water Supply System

In company with the Indian Agent, Mr. Moore, I inspected the water supply system at the above institution on October 7. It had been reported to this office by the Indian Commissioner that difficulty had been experienced in keeping the plant in operation.

I found the pumping plant to be operating satisfactorily but was informed by the caretaker that he did not allow the plant to work automatically as intended as he was afraid of something happening. Consequently the pump is started manually when the supply of water in the pressure tank becomes low. There does not appear to be any particular reason why the plant should not operate as intended.

In reviewing the repairs effected to date, I noted as follows:

The plant was installed in December, 1939. In July, 1941 the motor starting coil burned out and had to be removed. In January, 1943 the motor burned out and had to be removed. In June, 1943 pressure switch ceased to function and had to be replaced. The local electrician who has repaired the equipment on several occasions, informed me that he believed that the pressure switch had been frozen at some time as the diaphragm was found to be badly distorted. This of course could only occur in the winter and if so may have been the cause of the motor burning out in January of this year.
The type of motor repair required would appear to indicate an overload on the motor at times but none of the factors likely to cause overload appear to be present - line voltage is normal and the pump functions well when the motor runs, the pump being of non-overloading type.

It appears to me that if difficulties are to be avoided in future the well head shelter will have to be rebuilt to provide better protection from the weather or the pumping equipment will have to be moved into the school. I am very much in favour of the latter. In my mind there is little doubt that excessive moisture in the pump house is mainly responsible for the breakdowns and it may be that dampness cannot be entirely eliminated by reconstruction of the well head shelter.

It is estimated that the cost of rebuilding the shelter would amount to $95.00.

To move the pumping equipment into the school is estimated to cost $225.00. The equipment could be located in the storeroom now used for manual training tools, etc. This room will not be required when the partitioning of the large basement room now under way is completed.

[Signature]

W.E. Warren
Agent, Hydraulic Engineer

I beg to forward herewith a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Moore regarding the supply of tables and stools required for the domestic science division of St. Catherine's Indian Day School, together with a quotation on the equipment required submitted by the Cowichan Joinery Works, Duncan.

When the matter was brought to my attention during a recent visit to the school, I suggested that what was needed might be made at the school under the direction of the manual training instructor, Mr. Morrison. The Principal, however, pointed out that equipment of this kind would take quite a long time to make and would engage almost the entire attention of the manual training instructor, leaving little time for general instruction in manual training to the boys taking this course. She also explained that Mr. Morrison was, at present, employed on flooring part of the basement of the school and building a partition, work that required skill and care in order that it would be similar in quality to the surrounding construction and, consequently, very little of it could be entrusted to the boys who had received very little instruction to date in proper use of tools. The Principal's contention is simply that the manual training instructor should be free to carry out the program set down for the manual training division and not engaged on work, the major part of which he has to do himself, without any resulting benefit to his pupils.

Equipment along the lines suggested is necessary and it probably would be as well to purchase part or all of it if funds are available and I would so recommend. The Department's decision in this matter at an early date would be appreciated.

In November of 1942 a request was received from the Reverend Principal of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School for a number of desks, but no action was taken at that time as the attendance at the School did not justify the expenditure.

I am now in receipt of a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Moore to the effect that the attendance at this School has improved considerably and that a very creditable average attendance is expected in the future.

It is, therefore, proposed to supply extra seating accommodation at this School and I beg to enclose herewith quotation from Mr. Walter Cline, B. C. Representative of the Globe Furniture Company, on the desks required.

If funds are available for this expenditure, I would recommend same for your approval.

D. M. MacKay.
Indian Commissioner for B. C.

July 17th, 1944.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver.

With further reference to previous correspondence regarding Fire Extinguishers for the St. Catherines Indian Day School, and in reply to your letter above noted. I wish to advise that I have just finished discussing this question with the local traveller of McLellan, McFeely and Prior, and find that by buying these Extinguishers direct from the above Firm in Victoria we can get a suitable implement for $16.00 each, F.C.B. Victoria. The Extinguishers which I would recommend is:

"The 2½ Gall. Guardene Fire Extinguisher"

These are Soda Extinguishers and the refills are quite inexpensive, furthermore they are the type that is commonly used in schools.

I believe that we can get along with five of these kind of extinguishers for the St. Catherines School, while there should be one ordered for the Koksilah School too, and I would so recommend.

"R. H. Moore"
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of July 17th, with reference to the supply of fire extinguishers to the St. Catherine's and Koksilah Indian Day School.

An amount of $60.00 was entered in the Estimates for the supply of extinguishers to St. Catherine's School and $10.00 for the Koksilah School, for the same purpose.

It will be noted that a suitable implement can be secured at $16.00 each, f.o.b. Victoria, and I would recommend that authority be granted for the purchase of four extinguishers for St. Catherine's School and one for Koksilah School.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
Ottawa,
July 31, 1944.

Mr. Indian Agent Moore recently requested authority to rent an extension ladder for use in cleaning the eaves-troughs at the St. Catherine's Indian Day School. Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver,

With reference to your above noted letter authorising the purchase of an extension ladder for use at the St. Catherine's Indian Day School. I wish to advise that this has been on order since the authority was received but unfortunately delivery has not yet been made, and Mac & Mac's traveller tells me that he is not sure just when we will be able to get it.

In the meantime the cove troughs at the school had to be attended to as the weight of water and coal dust in them caused them to bend in the middle to just about the breaking pint and consequently to avoid greater expense it was necessary for us to get a ladder in a hurry and the cost of this, largely on account of the delivery charges both to and from the school, was $2.50. Voucher in payment of this is attached hereto and I would ask you to be good enough to approve it and forward to the Department for payment.

The total mileage involved for the two return trips is ten miles.

(R.H. Moore)

Duncan, B.C:

Dear Sir,—

We wish to call to your attention that our Contract with the Department, for the transportation of Indian School Children to and from St. Catherine's and Koksilah Indian Day Schools, expires at the end of June this year and would respectfully request that a renewal of this Contract, as now in effect or changes which the Department wish to make.

March 3rd, 1945

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver,

I beg to submit herewith a letter, and copy of same, which I trust you will find self-explanatory.

In this regard I might say that this Company has given us really good service during the past five years and as the contract was originally drawn up and entered into on the understanding that it covered a period of 10 months annually, this in fact has not been the case, for with the exception of the last two years we have only had an eight and nine month school year, which has really not been quite fair to the operator—especially as he had to go to the expense of getting a new Bus.

I would recommend that the contract be renewed for another five years on the same terms and conditions. Mr Kyle has been very good in giving extra services to the pupils of this school at various times such as at Christmas, when he has run special bus to take the children to and from the school after they have put on their annual school concert. He has also taken the children to various sports events without cost either to the children or their parents, which I feel was very good of him.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of March 3rd and enclosure referred to therein in connection with the proposed renewal of the contract with the Cowichan Valley Bus and Taxi Service for transportation of pupils to and from St. Catherine's Indian Day School. The present five year contract expires June 30, 1945, and in view of the Agent's recommendation and the excellent service given by the Company, it is recommended that the contract be renewed for a further five years on the same terms and conditions.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

WHEREAS the Department is required to provide for transportation to and from school of certain school children; and WHEREAS in the pursuance of such requirement the Department has entered into an arrangement with the Contractors for such means of transportation and these presents are for the purpose of setting out the terms and conditions of the agreement entered into by the parties hereto.

NOW THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that it is agreed by and between the respective parties hereto the Contractors agreeing jointly and severally as follows:

1. The Contractors shall inaugurate and maintain during the period commencing on the 1st day of January 1940 and terminating on the 30th day of June 1945 (both days being included in the period) a motor vehicle service for the purpose of conveying and shall convey in a motor vehicle or motor vehicles from such school or schools as the Department shall from time designate and notify to the Contractors within the premises of the Cowichan Indian Reserve such children as are...
from time to time be designated by the Department or its Agent and notified by it to the Contractors.

2. Subject to Section 3(4) of the Regulations under the "Motor-Vehicle Act" set forth in an Order of the Lieutenant-Governor in Council dated the 18th day of April 1936 each child shall be taken on board the vehicle on its way to the school and shall be permitted to alight on the return journey from the school at such points on the said route as may from time to time be designated by the Department.

3. The Contractors shall maintain the service along the following routes that is to say:

A. Leave the Somonos Indian Village on the Cowichan Indian Reserve proceeding northerly along the Island Highway turning east on to the Trunk Road and Victoria Road to the new Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School, thence via the old Victoria Road through the Cowichan Indian Reserve to the Island Highway, thence westerly along said highway to the Koksilah Mission Road, thence north to Koksilah Mission near the Koksilah Indian School, thence returning over the same route to the said Consolidated Indian Day School.

B. Leave the said Consolidated Indian Day School and proceed via the old Victoria Road and Cowichan Indian Reserve and the Island Highway, thence westerly to the Koksilah Mission Road, thence north to Koksilah Mission near Koksilah Indian School, thence returning by the same route to said Consolidated Indian Day School, thence west to said Somonos Indian Village via the old Victoria Road to the Island Highway as per plan attached.

4. The Contractors shall maintain such service on each and every school day during the currency of this agreement and shall so time the passage of the vehicle along the route reasonably so as to deliver and the Contractors shall deliver the passengers at the schools so designated as aforesaid not later than 8:55 o'clock in the forenoon of each school day and shall have the vehicle at the schools to take up the passengers at such times in the afternoon as shall be designated by the Department or its Agent in the afternoon of each school day.

5. When proceeding along the route the driver of the vehicle shall sound a distinctive warning by horn or otherwise when approaching any point at which any child or children is or are in the habit of entering the vehicle and shall use all proper and reasonable means to ensure the transportation to and from a school of all children so designated as aforesaid.

6. The Contractors shall comply with all and every the provisions of the Motor-Vehicle Act (Revised Statutes of British Columbia 1936 Chapter 195) and any amendments thereto now or hereafter in force and applicable and in particular shall comply with the said Regulations set forth in the said Order of the Lieutenant-Governor in Council and any other regulations and orders now or which may hereafter from time to time be in force and applicable.

7. The Contractors shall maintain a good safe efficient and punctual service and shall equip and operate all vehicles in such manner as will ensure the reasonable comfort and shelter of the passengers therein PROVIDED ALWAYS that the Contractors

MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT made this Seventeenth day of April in the year of our Lord One thousand nine hundred and forty-five BETWEEN: HIS MAJESTY THE KING IN THE RIGHT OF CANADA AS REPRESENTED BY THE DIRECTOR OF THE INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH OF THE DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES hereinafter called "the Department" of the one part and J. A. KYLE of the City of Duncan in the Province of British Columbia carrying on business as Cowichan Valley Bus and Taxi Services (Kyle) and HOWARD VALENTINE KYLE of the said City of Duncan (hereinafter called "the Contractors") of the other part.

WHEREAS the Department is required to provide for the transportation to and from school of certain school children

AND WHEREAS in the pursuance of such requirement the Department has entered into an arrangement with the contractors for such means of transportation and these presents are for the purpose of setting out the terms and conditions of the agreement entered into by the parties hereto

NOW THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that it is agreed by and between the respective parties hereto the Contractors agreeing jointly and severally as follows:-

1. The Contractors shall inaugurate and maintain during the period commencing on the 1st day of July 1945 and terminating on the 30th day of June 1950 (both days being included in the period) a motor vehicle service for the purpose of conveying and shall convey in a motor vehicle or motor vehicles to and from such school or schools as the Department shall from time to time designate and notify to the Contractors within the boundaries of the Cowichan Indian Reserve such children
as shall from time to time be designated by the Department or its Agent and notified by it to the Contractors.

2. Subject to Section 21 (d) of the Regulations under the "Motor-Vehicle Act" set forth in an Order of the Lieutenant-Governor in Council dated the 12th day of April 1935 each child shall be taken on board the vehicle on its way to the school and shall be permitted to alight on the return journey from the school at such points on the said route as may from time to time be designated by the Department.

3. The Contractors shall maintain the service along the following routes that is to say:

A. M. Leave the Somenos Indian village on the Cowichan Indian Reserve proceeding northerly along the Island Highway turning east on to the Trunk road and Victoria road to the new Cowichan Consolidated Indian Day School, thence via the old Victoria road through the Cowichan Indian Reserve to the Island Highway, thence westerly along said highway to the Koksilah Mission road, thence north to Koksilah Mission near the Koksilah Indian School, thence returning over the same route to the said Consolidated Indian Day School.

P. M. Leave the said Consolidated Indian Day School and proceed via the old Victoria road and Cowichan Indian Reserve and the Island Highway, thence westerly to the Koksilah Mission road, thence north to Koksilah Mission near Koksilah Indian School, thence returning by the same route to said Consolidated Indian Day School, thence west to said Somenos Indian Village via the old Victoria road to the Island Highway as per plan attached.
4. The Contractors shall maintain such service on each and every school day during the currency of this agreement and shall so time the passage of the vehicle along the route reasonably so as to deliver and the Contractors shall deliver the passengers at the schools so designated as aforesaid not later than 8:55 o'clock in the forenoon of each school day and shall have the vehicle at the schools to take up the passengers at such times in the afternoon as shall be designated by the Department or its Agent in the afternoon of each school day and shall proceed forthwith to transport and shall transport each of them to his or her destination along the route.

5. When proceeding along the route the driver of the vehicle shall sound a distinctive warning by horn or otherwise when approaching any point at which any child or children is or are in the habit of entering the vehicle and shall use all proper and reasonable means to ensure the transportation to and from a school of all children so designated as aforesaid.

6. The Contractors shall comply with all and every the provisions of the Motor-Vehicle Act (Revised Statutes of British Columbia 1936 Chapter 195) and any amendments thereto now or hereafter in force and applicable and in particular shall comply with the said Regulations set forth in the said Order of the Lieutenant-Governor in Council and any other regulations and orders now or which may hereafter from time to time be in force and applicable.

7. The Contractors shall maintain a good safe efficient and punctual service and shall equip and operate all vehicles in such manner as will ensure the reasonable comfort and shelter of the passengers therein PROVIDED ALWAYS that the Contractors
shall not be bound to maintain the service upon any route during such time as it shall be rendered impassable or dangerous by reason of deep snow or other cause beyond the control of the Contractors but the Contractors shall not be entitled to any remuneration during such time.

8. The Contractors shall at the Contractors' own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in respect of each vehicle against public liability and against loss of life and injury to the children who may be passengers in any vehicle and any person carried therein accompanying or in charge of such children or any of them in an Insurance Company or Insurance Companies approved by the Department and such insurance shall cover the Contractors and all or any liability of the Department in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the claim of any one individual and in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one accident and in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for damage to property and the Contractors shall punctually pay all premiums in respect of such insurance and deliver the receipts for such premiums to the Department and produce the policies to the Department for inspection upon demand.

9. The Contractors shall also at the Contractors' own expense effect and keep in effect insurance in favour of the Department against non-owners liability in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for or in respect of any legal liability of the Department for bodily injury to or the death of any one person and subject to
such limit for any one person so injured or killed in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) (exclusive of interest and costs) for bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident and any policy for such insurance shall also extend to and cover all school children their attendants or teachers while being transported to or from school to or from games and to or from outings in the personal charge of the Department while in a motor vehicle operated by the Contractors. The premiums for such insurance shall be paid by the Contractors and all and every policy for such insurance shall be in the name of the Department.

10. The Contractors shall employ as drivers and assistants of vehicles competent chauffeurs of good moral character and at once shall cease to employ any person as driver or assistant on any vehicle if so requested in writing by the Department.

11. The Contractors shall maintain the service solely for the transportation of children to and from school as aforesaid and no person other than the chauffeur or an employee of the Contractors' assistant to the chauffeur or any teacher or teachers in the employ of the Department shall be permitted to be on board any vehicle at any time while engaged in such service.

12. The remuneration to be paid by the Department to the Contractors for the service hereunder shall be calculated as follows:

The sum of thirty-five (35) cents per mile per day for all children up to the number of thirty (30) and for the purpose of calculating such remuneration the said route shall be deemed to measure thirty-two (32) miles inclusive of the inward and return trips twice a day, the Contractor to
submit his account for the service at the end of each month for payment, subject to any adjustment or correction by the Department.

THE CONTRACTORS shall transport any children over and above the number prescribed for any route if the vehicle in use has sufficient capacity therefor but shall not be entitled to any further remuneration for any children above the prescribed number so transported PROVIDED ALWAYS that in the event of the circumstances prescribed in the Schedule hereto taking place in respect of either of the said Routes the said remuneration may be varied from time to time upon notice in writing given by either party hereto to the other party and thereupon such variation shall take place as from the date of service of such notice calculated in accordance with provisions applicable as set forth in the said Schedule.

13. The service shall not be continued and the said remuneration shall not be payable during the usual school vacations nor shall the service be continued nor shall the remuneration be payable during any period other than the said vacations when the schools shall be closed.

14. The Department shall have power from time to time to change any route by any variation extension or modification thereof PROVIDED that in the event of any such extension the Department shall pay to the Contractor as remuneration an additional amount per mile or part of a mile by which the route is so extended calculated at the rate provided in Clause 12 hereof in respect of such route and in the event of any modification of a route the remuneration of the Contractors shall be reduced by an amount per mile or part of a mile by which the route is so modified calculated at the rate provided in
Clause 18 hereof in respect of such route and in the event of any dispute as to the measurement of any such extension or modification such measurement shall be ascertained by a British Columbia Land Surveyor whose fees shall be paid as to one-half thereof by the Department and as to the remaining one-half thereof by the Contractors.

15. Subject to Clause 14 hereof it is agreed that in the event of any dispute difference or question arising between the said parties hereto out of the construction or carrying out of the terms of these presents the same shall be referred to Arbitration pursuant to the Arbitration Act.

16. The remuneration payable to the Contractor shall be paid to them by the Department direct by cheque or to such person or persons corporation or corporations as the Contractors may from time to time request the Department in writing PROVIDED ALWAYS that nothing herein contained shall have effect as permitting the Contractors to assign or transfer their obligations under this agreement.

17. The Department shall have the option of cancelling this agreement at any time by ninety days notice to the Contractors by notice sent by registered mail addressed to him at Duncan, British Columbia and if any of the conditions in paragraphs 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 and 11 are not complied with by the Contractors the contract shall terminate forthwith without notice and no action for damages shall lie against His Majesty.

18. Wherever the context so requires or admits the expression "the Contractors" hereinbefore used shall extend to and include the survivor of them to the intent and so that the obligations
hereby imposed upon or assumed by the Contractors shall be binding upon and performed by such survivor.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, on behalf of the Minister, and the Contractors have hereunto set their hands and seals the day and year first above written.

Ottawa, June 27th, 1945.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, with reference to Domestic Science equipment requisitioned for the St. Catherine's Indian Day School. On reviewing the list of pupils who are taking the Domestic Science course, it is noted that only ten of them attend school over one hundred days. In other words, not more than ten of these have been present much more than half the school year. This means that the daily attendance at the Domestic Science work is by no means large.

With the above in mind it is felt that equipment costing not more than $50.00 should be sufficient and authority is granted for the expenditure of the amount stated.

If the Domestic Science class increases during the coming academic year and if the pupils in the class attend regularly more equipment might be necessary. In this event you can make a further application.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's requisition of April 27th, 1945, for domestic science equipment for St. Catherine's Indian Day School amounting to an approximate cost of $150.00, together with a copy of my enquiry of the 14th ultimo to Mr. Moore and his reply of the 18th instant from which it would appear that the Agent has not modified his original recommendation contained in the requisition.

I consider the requisition excessive and an expenditure of $30.00 to $40.00 for this material should be ample. It would be appreciated if the Department would advise what they consider a satisfactory list for this school with the limited number of domestic science pupils as set out by Mr. Moore.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

You will please remember that we discussed the drainage from the kitchen or domestic science room at the St. Catherine's Indian School during your last visit there and I showed you just how it operated, simply draining through soil pipes about 100' from the building and spilling out on the top of the ground.

Sometimes the odor from the outlet is most obnoxious, not to mention the other drawbacks to such a system of disposal, and so I decided that it would be advisable to have the caretaker dig a hole 6 feet deep—which it is thought will get us into gravel—and four feet square on top, then fill this hole with rocks or small boulders from the river to within about a foot from the top, carry the water from the outlet down by soil pipes to almost the bottom of the hole and the rocks, then refill the top of the hole with earth for about a foot in depth which will bring it up level with the surrounding ground.

This will require an expenditure for rocks to be hauled from the river of $12.00 to $15.00 plus the cost of pipes amounting to about $1.00 or a total maximum of $16.00.

I would also like authority to expend the sum of $10.00 in having gravel and sand hauled to place under the swings etc., at the same school as there are holes being dug now and it becomes very wet and muddy during the wet rainy weather. Your kind attention to this at your early convenience.

(R.H. Moore) Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of September 26th wherein he requests authority for an expenditure of $26.00 for improvements at the St. Catherines Indian Day School. The expenditure would appear to be necessary and I have authorized Mr. Moore to proceed with the work, which action I trust will meet with your approval.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Philip Phelan,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Mr. Acting Indian Agent Caldwell's letter of November 30th in connection with transportation of children to the St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

It will be noted that the capacity of the school bus is exceeded to the extent of 10 or 12 pupils and that Mr. Kyle, the operator, is carrying the extra children by taxi at an additional cost of $3.00 per day. This condition is apparently caused by the Clemclemaluts bridge being closed for repairs and is unavoidable; in view of which it is recommended that the Department authorize the additional expenditure until such time as the bridge is repaired.

D.M. MacKay,

November 30th, 1945

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

Further to our letter of May 21st last regarding the Contract for transportation of school children on the Cowichan I.R., I beg to advise that the Operators of the Bus have informed me that at the present time their Bus is overcrowded to the extent of 10 to 12 pupils. Its capacity is 50 persons and there are over 60 wanting transportation to and from school.

Mr Kyle has offered to carry the extra children in his large Taxi at a cost of $1.50 per trip which would mean a total expenditure of $3.00 per day. Pending your approval to this request I have authorised Mr Kyle to use his Taxi at the above rates.

This condition is expected to continue until the Clamclamutz Bridge is repaired and which is supposed to be completed in another week or ten days.

J.D. Caldwell,

The grates and Ash Pit are burnt out. Also the first section of the Fire Pot is burnt out. The second section is cracked and we found the feed pouch to be badly warped.

In view of the fact that it would cost a great deal to repair this furnace in such a manner that it would give satisfaction, we respectfully submit that some thought should be given to the purchase of a new one. We suggest that an all steel Heavy Duty Furnace which could be installed at a cost of $350.00 (Complete) would in the long run prove more economical than having the old furnace repaired. These all steel heavy duty furnaces have proven themselves and we can assure you that they give entire satisfaction.

Trusting that you will give this matter your consideration and that we may be favoured with your instructions, we are,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Manager.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

February 5th, 1946.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

I beg to attach herewith in duplicate a letter received from the local Plumber relative to the present condition of the furnace of St. Catherine's Indian Day School, and which I trust you may find self-explanatory.

On the 1st inst. it was reported to me that the inside of the fire box of this furnace had broken down and the janitor was unable to put any more fire on. I got in touch with the Plumber and asked him to go out and examine it and advise just what was wrong. Owing to the fact that the fire was still on and the furnace hot he could not make a proper inspection until the following day, and on which I did not receive his report until yesterday.

Mr. Griffiths recommends the installation of a complete new furnace at a total cost of $320.00 installed, and which it is expected he will be able to procure almost immediately from Victoria or Vancouver. He considers that the old furnace is so badly used up that it would not be economical to make the necessary repairs, even providing we could get the required parts in a reasonable time—which he explains might take two months at least judging from his recent experiences in getting parts. However, to find out all the parts that would have to be renewed it would mean the complete dismantling of the furnace. Going on estimated costs of the known parts that will be required, plus the labor costs involved in making the repairs, it would appear as if the difference in the price of these repairs and the new furnace would be about $70.00, and then with the warping of some of the parts that might not need to be renewed it is extremely doubtful if we would ever have economic operation.

Major D. M. MacKay

Post Office Box 70
Vancouver, B.C.

I beg to apply for authority to have approximately 30 yards of fine gravel hauled for the driveways at St. Catherine's School at a cost of $2.00 per yard delivered and spread. This is required now so that it can be hauled before the school reopens and may have a chance to settle a little so that it will not be carried into the school on the feet of the pupils.

I would also ask for authority to engage an Indian with a team for two days to cut the grass on the school grounds within the next week or ten days before it has a chance to dry up and become a fire menace not only to the grounds and surrounding bush but to the building itself. It is customary to cut and haul this grass and weeds off the grounds entirely to the dump and last year it took two days to do it. The cost for this will be $10.00 per day or a total of $20.00.

St. Catherine's Indian Day School

We have recently received a request from the Principal of the above school that indoor toilet facilities be installed. Upon writing to the Agent concerning this matter, we received a reply which reads as follows:

"I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter above noted with enclosure from the Department relative to the installation of indoor toilet facilities at St. Catherine's Day School. For your information I would like to advise that this matter is much more involved than it appears on the surface owing to the fact that there is no room at present in the school building suitable even for the installation of toilets for the staff. In my opinion these will require to be accommodated in an addition to the building proper, certainly so if lavatories for the pupils are intended and which I have got to estimate the cost of. As you know this will entail knowledge of the water system and the feasibility of bringing it to a certain part of the building as well as probable changes in the structural plans of the school. I would therefore like to ask that one of the engineers from the Water and Power Bureau be asked to look into this matter as I feel it would be much more satisfactory. If this is not done I will have to get estimated costs from the local plumber and possibly from the building contractor. How the Department will feel about building..."
an addition to the school for the purposes under review is in my opinion not very hopeful."

It is therefore requested that at some time in the near future one of your officials visit the school and make a report upon the work necessary to install running water toilets for the teachers and pupils at this school.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: St. Catherine's Indian Day School,
Cowichan Indian Agency, B.C.

In connection with the points raised in Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you dated November 1st, copy of which was forwarded to us bearing your notation of the 5th instant, we may say that the School in question was never intended to be served by flush toilets for teachers or pupils and we do not consider it an economical undertaking at this time.

The St. Catherine's School was planned to make full use of all space. The Indian Agent comments correctly, therefore, when he says "there is no room at present in the School building even for the installation of toilets for the staff".

To arrange for flush toilets, it would be necessary to carry out major structural alterations to the building, provide a larger pump and pressure tank, build a septic tank, and install a sewage disposal bed. Toilet fixtures could not be accommodated in any existing space and appendages to the building added for the purpose, which could only be reached through Classrooms, would definitely spoil the attractive appearance of the building. These added rooms would, of course, even in British Columbia require some heating and the present hot air system of heating is not large enough to carry any extensions.

It is felt that Indian Affairs would not be prepared to spend the necessary funds for the items involved which, under present circumstances, are very roughly estimated to be in the neighbourhood of $5,000.00.

Under these circumstances, no purpose would be served in sending an officer to Duncan, and it is recommended that the School be allowed to remain as at present. Unless instructed to the contrary, therefore, this Service will take no further action on the matter.

T. S. Mills.
Chief Engineer.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

June 24, 1947.

With reference to your letter of June 6th, and particularly to the second paragraph of same, I wish to advise that, if you refer to purchase order No. 14605, dated November 6th, 1946, you will notice that an order was given to the Singer Sewing Machine Company, Vancouver, for two Singer Sewing Machines at a total cost of $79.48. One of these machines was for use at the Tsartlip Indian Day School, Sr. Room, and the other at the Saanich Indian Day School. Owing to the fact that these machines were so long in arriving the teacher at the Tsartlip School borrowed one from one of the Indian women to use in the interval.

Although I have written on several occasions to the Singer Sewing Machine Company, in Vancouver, I was unable to get any action, nor any explanation as to the cause of the delay and just today I received a letter from them, dated June 19th, stating that they have no record of any such Purchase Order ever having been received although, according to my information, it was sent to them direct from Ottawa -- file No. 68547-15-20-1, 152-22-5, November 6th, 1946.

Kindly check on this at your convenience and advise. If possible, have a copy of the Purchase Order sent to the Sewing Machine Company so that we may receive these machines without any further undue delay.

R. H. MOORE
Indian Agent.

Reference is made to the above and request of the Indian Agent, Cowichan Indian Agency, Duncan, B.C., who has asked the assistance of this detachment in regard to the collecting the sum of $10.00 from the subject concerning damage done to the fence at the St. Catharine's Indian Day School, Duncan, B.C., by a driver of the subject's truck.

Mr. R.H. Moore, Indian Agent, Duncan, B.C., has forwarded to this office a copy of a letter which he has sent to the subject, and claims that he has not received any reply. The following is copied hereunder:

Duncan, B.C.,
June 2, 1947.

"BEGINS"

Mar Chew,
625 Chatham St.,
VICTORIA, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I wrote you on April 14th last, regarding the driver of your truck who backed into the fence at St. Catherine's Indian Day School, on Cowichan Indian Reserve, breaking off fence posts and part of the top rail and driving away without stopping or reporting the damage to the caretaker at the School. I also stated, at that time, that if you were prepared to pay the sum of $10.00 to cover the damage no charge would be laid. You have failed to reply to my letter and I am bringing the matter to your attention with the request for an early reply.

Yours truly,

SIGNED

R.H. Moore
Indian Agent.

"ENDS"

On the 19th inst., the subject was interviewed by the writer concerning the damage of the fence in question. He advises that he has replied to the Indian Agent's letter of June 2nd, 1947, and is still at a loss to understand the charges made by the Indian Agent. CHEW stated that he owns one vegetable truck which he operates at Victoria, B.C., he employs no truck driver, nor has he a license to operate at Duncan, B.C. The subject claims that he has made enquiries among our Chinese peddlers who truck fruit and vegetables to...
VEGETABLES TO the Duncan area, from Victoria, B.C., in hopes that this matter could be cleared up. However, he stated no one was able to throw any light on the matter.

4. The vegetable truck operated by the subject here at Victoria, is a Chevrolet 1929 model, 1/2 ton B.C. License No. C.D.396, and is pale green in color.

5. Further enquiries were made by the writer, with nil results. This file is being closed here, unless otherwise instructed.

CONCLUDED HERE.

I wish to advise that there is another transportation problem for school children on the Cowichan I. R. No. 3, which has cropped up.

There are seven children, between the ages of 13 and 7, residing on this Reserve, who should be at school. Their names and particulars are as follows:

| CHILD'S NAME | AGE | PARENT OR GUARDIAN | BAND AND NUMBER |
|--------------|-----|--------------------|-----------------|
| Clarence WILSON | 13  | Albert Wilson      | #77 Cowichan Band |
| Nelson WILSON   | 11  | Albert Wilson      | #77 Cowichan Band |
| Cloero AUGUST    | 7   | Edward August (G.P.) | #47 Somenos Band |
| John Baptiste JACK | 7   | Frank Jack         | #35 Clowemelmut Band |
| Barbara DICK     | 11  | Robbie Daniels (G.P.) | #1 Kilpaulus Band |
| Ronald DICK      | 10  | Robbie Daniels (G.P.) | #1 Kilpaulus Band |
| Richard DICK     | 8   | Robbie Daniels (G.P.) | #1 Kilpaulus Band |

The three last named belong to the West Coast Agency but, as their Mother died some one and one-half years ago, they have been cared for by their grandparents.

There is no room for any of these children to attend any Residential School and the parents can look after them satisfactorily.

My recommendation is that we arrange for their transportation from Cowichan Bay to the Tennis Court corner, a distance of two and one-half miles, (which is about half way along the South line of the Cowichan I. R. #9) where they could board our regular bus and go to their respective schools -- either Eoksishal or St. Catherine's. The transportation would be arranged by Taxi from Cowichan Bay in the a.m. and then it would pick them up off the road in the afternoon about 3:40 p.m. The total distance travelled by Taxi -- two trips daily -- would be ten miles, at a daily cost of two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50). The operator of this Taxi is fully ensured and is most reliable.

I hope this may receive your early, and favourable, consideration.

R. H. MOORE
Indian Agent.
