Please refer to my letter of August 20th, last, to which yours, above noted, was in reply.

On September 15th, Rev. Sister Mary Sheila was notified, by letter, that the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) per month had been authorized with which to purchase materials to provide a hot drink for the pupils at St. Catherine's Indian Day School each day.

On September 30th I received a letter from the Rev. Sister asking that at least another two dollars ($2.00) per month be granted.

On October 1st Sister Sheila was authorized to expend the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) per month for cooking supplies.

About one week later, I told the Rev. Sister that, as I had applied on August 20th for twelve dollars ($12.00) per month for supplies for hot drinks and only ten dollars ($10.00) had been authorized, I could not see the necessity of applying again, particularly as the attendance at that time was not any more than 50 or 60 pupils and the school was already receiving another $10.00 per month for cooking supplies.

I now wish to attach a copy of a letter recently received from the Rev. Sister which I hope may be found self-explanatory.

Personally, I feel her comparison with the amount Koksilah school is receiving is unfair. The average attendance at St.
Catherine's school during the last quarter of the 1946-47 Academic Year was less than 20% of her pupilage and this should have allowed her to get a little ahead in her supplies. Furthermore, the same facilities for the economic preparation of the hot drinks do not exist at the Koksilah Indian Day School. Some of the children in attendance at the Koksilah School have to leave home earlier in the morning and they get home later in the evening than those at St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

Your kind consideration to this request from the Sister will be appreciated.

Dear Sir:

With reference to overloading an School Bus transporting Indian children from Kokislah, Clemlemaluts and Stone Church areas to and from St. Catherine's Indian Day School, this has reached a serious stage and we regret we must ask your co-operation and help in reducing this overload in order that we may comply with Provincial Motor Vehicle Regulations and Passenger Hazard Insurance coverage.

During the past School month, there have been fifteen days on which loads, over and above the maximum of 50 children, have been carried. In one case, on the 24th of November, there were 64 children carried from the above mentioned areas; on four occasions 55 have been transported, on one trip 58, and on another 59. Remainder of the 15 trips above-mentioned varied with loads of 52 and 54.

You can appreciate our position in the event of an accident of any character during the time the bus was overloaded, and we cannot at the present time, allow a larger load than 50 to be carried on the bus at any one time.

The only solution to the problem at present is that a sufficient number of pupils from the Stone Church area be transported by other means to the extent that the overloading be obviated.

Thanking you for your past co-operation and assuring you of our continued service and co-operation.

Yours truly,

Cowichan Motor Transport (Kyle) Ltd.

This will raise the charge by approximately $1.60 per day or eighty cents (80¢) each trip -- extra trips to be kept track of by the school principal.

If I had not done this now it would mean that approximately eight children would not be coming to school as most of the eight who are picked up at the stone church, each day, have already had to walk one and one-half to two miles from their homes, at Khenipsen village, across the Dyke.

Re: Transportation St. Catherines Indian Day School

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of December 1st and enclosure referred to therein regarding over-crowding of the St. Catherine's school bus. You will note that the bus is authorized to carry 30 passengers only, but that on many days the number of children to be transported is in excess of 30 and on one day reached a total of 64. Our present agreement with the Company provides for payment of 3½ per mile per day over a 32 mile route, both return trips included, for up to 30 children, an average cost of 37½ per child. If the number to be transported is in excess of 30 the agreement provides for payment of 40½ per mile per day over the 32 mile route on an average cost of 25½ per child for 30 children.

The proposed payment of $1.60 per day for the extra trip necessary to transport children over and above the 30 which can be carried on the first trip will, assuming there is an average of 55 children per day, result in an approximate cost of 28½ per child which is not unreasonable. I would recommend that Mr. Moore be authorized to submit accounts at the rate of 35½ per mile per day for up to 30 children transported, 40½ per mile per day where the number is in excess of 30 and not over 50, and 40½ per mile per day plus an additional $1.60 when the number is in excess of 50.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Drainage, Grounds,
St. Catherines Indian Day School,
Cowichan Agency.

Following your instructions, a visit was made on November 28, 1947, to the St. Catherines Indian Day School in the company of Mr. Indian Agent Moore. It was desired to inspect the playgrounds with the view of enlargement and drainage.

On November 29, 1947, levels were taken in the area in question, to determine slopes and low points. The area under consideration is the playground located behind the school building, as shown on attached plan.

The chief difficulty with drainage lies in the fact that there is a slight hollow in the centre of the playground which holds the water and causes the ground to be muddy for several days after a heavy rain. The playground slopes to the west, and it is recommended that a 4-inch agricultural tile drain be laid from the low spot mentioned above and be connected to the 6-inch tile pipe leading from the school house. About 80 feet of 4-inch pipe would be required. This pipe would afford drainage of this low point in the centre of the present baseball diamond.
It was thought that the grounds could be extended toward the south boundary, by clearing out brush and small trees. In this connection, some earth could be backfilled into low points on the grounds from the cleared area, as the grounds have a gentle upward slope toward the south boundary. This latter suggestion does not obviate the necessity of installing the tile drain, as a certain amount of artificial drainage is necessary in any case. Appended to this memorandum is a topographical plan showing proposed clearing and drainage.

Conclusion

The work mentioned above might be carried out under the supervision of the Agent. The estimated cost is as follows:

- 80 lin. ft. 4" agricultural tile @ 10¢ ft. $ 8.00
- Ditching and laying above 80 ft. @ $1.00 ft. 30.00
- Bulldozer for grading, 3 days @ $75 per day 225.00
- Contingencies 15% - 47.00

$360.00

I have received a request from Rev. Father L. LeClair that I apply to the Department for permission to allow the Reverend Sisters, who are employed as teachers at St. Catherine's Indian Day School, to use the school building one evening each week for educational and social purposes for the teen-age girls of the Cowichan Band. These girls will be, to a large degree, present pupils of the school, as well as older girls who have left school.

The proposal is that short talks will be given the girls by appropriate speakers. Pictures of some educational value will be shown, and occasionally a social evening will be held when senior or teen-age boys will be invited. The ages will be from thirteen to nineteen or twenty years.

I realize that this proposal is rather unusual, and may be fraught with some misgivings. However, these teen-age youths are a cause of concern to me, as far too many of them are getting into difficulties, largely on account of the fact that there is no provision made for their recreational or social activities, for the long winter evenings, either during the time they are attending school, or after they reach the age of 16 years. The fact that these meetings will be attended by the Sisters should, I hope, be sufficient guarantee that they will look after the school and the furnishings, as well as the girls, so that so far as the Department is concerned, no great damage may be expected to either building, or contents. If such a thing should happen, the authority -- if given -- could be cancelled.

I would recommend, however, that the club or organization, do the required cleaning up themselves after each meeting instead of leaving it to the Caretaker. In other words, any arranging of desks or furniture -- either before or after the gathering -- be the responsibility of the club, and not the Caretaker.

As you know, the Cowichan Band has not a Community Hall or meeting place of any kind for their members, other than these iniquitous "Big Houses", in which they hold their Indian dances and which, if I had my way and could do it legally, would be burned down.

Your early consideration of this request will be appreciated.

R. H. BURKE,
Indian Agent.

I have received a request from the Principal of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School that a telephone be installed at that school.

Dear Mr. Moore:

As the sun hits the two back classrooms facing directly south from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. it is necessary to keep the blinds up the whole school day. Hence we cannot get a breath of air in the hot weather and have to turn on the lights in order to work. The heat becomes so intense from lack of air that the children wilt and are incapable of effort. We have tried the window shades being pulled down and now have them working from the bottom, up. They are worn out from incessant use and have to be renewed.

I have priced awnings. Enclosed find quotations. I have also made out requisition forms for same. The initial output is quite steep but I feel sure that the satisfaction received will outweigh the cost. Personally, I would advocate the ten windows having separate awnings 3'6" instead of 7'6" covering two windows in spite of the extra cost, because it would be easier to handle them in taking them down and storing them during the winter months. They will then last over a period of years.

I would certainly appreciate this matter receiving a little consideration as the children will work more advantageously under these favourable conditions.

Yours truly,

DATE: June 16, 1948
Replying to yours of above date and file I would advise that I asked four different local contractors to give me a price for labor costs on the construction of a wall between two class-rooms at St. Catherine's Indian Day School but only one has acknowledged my request.

After a thorough inspection of the grounds and school building with Mr. Joe Garner, a local construction contractor, it was considered advisable to submit a quotation on the entire job necessary with the opening of the extra class-room.

1) Building the wall complete and in accordance with the existing walls, installation of blackboards, etc. ---- $528.00. It was considered that the original estimate of materials shown on the requisition of March 1st, last, was totally inadequate.

2) To lay the floor in the Domestic Science Room -- materials already there -- and covering same with Battleship linoleum, etc. ---- $520.00.

3) It was found that, after the playing field was levelled and graded, the water did not drain away from the upper end of the field as was expected. This condition was partly explained in your letter of May 13th, last, when I asked for fifty dollars ($50.00) to lay about 50' of tile drain which it was thought would be sufficient. However, the contractor claims that proper drainage can not be carried out unless we put down 200' -- the total cost of which will be $78.00. This is $28.00 more than authorized in your letter of the 9th instant, file number 3-11-3.

4) With the present enrollment at this school the existing outside toilets are not sufficient to take care of the pupils -- particularly the girls -- and, after discussing the matter with the Reverend Principal, we felt it advisable to get another twin unit the same as the present ones at an estimated cost of $117.00.

I hope the foregoing may be understood -- as well as the letter attached in duplicate. I know this seems to be a lot of money to expend at one time but, if the grounds had been fixed when the school was first built, it could have been done for twenty-five per cent of the outlay which we have made in small amounts each year.

Reverting to your letter of the 17th ultimo, file number 3-11-4, authorizing the construction and erection of new permanent swings for this school, I would advise that there has been a great deal of discussion as to where these should be erected so that they might be within constant view of the staff during recess and noon hour and, at the same time, be on firm, well drained ground. Here again the advice of the contractor was asked for and given as follows:

1) The place where the swings are to be placed (which will be within the view of the teachers at all times) should be raised up above the level of adjoining or surrounding areas so that, at no time, will the water lie either between the swings or in their immediate vicinity.

Having seen the small children playing on the present swings at this school with water lying in puddles at each one, it causes me to recommend that this be done before the new swings (now under construction) are erected in their permanent location. Total cost being $75.00. It would be too bad to put up these new swings and not make a real job of them.

I would recommend that the foregoing receive favourable consideration -- as well as the attached letter, in duplicate.

S. H. Moore, Superintendent, Cowichan Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re: St. Catherine's Indian Day School

I am enclosing Superintendent Moore's letter of June 2nd having reference to various expenditures necessary as set out below:

(1) Conversion of the present sewing room for use as a fourth classroom. Mr. Moore's original estimate of the cost of this work is now far too low. The cost of this work completed in accordance with tender supplied by Garner Brothers, Ltd., attached, will be $528.00.

(2) Completion of the floor in the domestic science room. Materials for this work were purchased previously and we had contemplated having the senior pupils in the manual training class provide the necessary labour. It is doubtful if this would be advisable, however, and to ensure proper completion of the work, particularly laying of linoleum, it is considered advisable to have it completed by experts. Garner Brothers quote a price of $520.00 complete.

(3) Installation of drainage tile on playing field. In your letter of June 1st, file 152-22-5 E.1, an expenditure of $66.40 was authorized for this work, which amount apparently has now been found insufficient for the purchase and installation of the quantity of tile necessary. The cost is now estimated at $78.00.

(4) Provision of an additional outside toilet - $117.00. It is anticipated that there will be an enrolment of approximately 120 pupils at St. Catherine's school during the next year and the present facilities are inadequate.
(5) Improvements to the site of the proposed new swings, reference Mr. Phelan's letter of May 14th, file 152-22-5 E.l, - $75.00.

(6) Painting and redecorating St. Catherine's school. This matter was the subject of correspondence last year, reference Mr. Neary's letter of July 28th, 1947, at which time it was considered advisable to defer redecorating of the interior and exterior until this year. The estimated cost of the work at that time was $1379, and Mr. Moore in his letter of June 26th attached suggests that the cost will not have increased to any extent at this time.

The total expenditure necessary for completion of the improvements above mentioned is approximately $2700. All the improvements referred to are undoubtedly necessary and should if possible be carried out this year. Please advise what funds can be made available so that if insufficient we may arrange to have the improvements carried out in order of priority.

St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

The above Indian Day School is situated near Duncan, British Columbia and is operated as a consolidated school with children being brought in daily by school bus.

The school is now ten years old and it is necessary to carry out certain repairs, particularly the conversion of the present sewing room for use as a fourth classroom. Indian Superintendent Moore approached four different local contractors for tenders on the repair and construction work required at this school.

Of these four contractors approached only one, Garner Brothers Limited submitted a tender as requested. It is recommended that this tender be approved by the Minister.

You will remember recent authorization to erect new swings at the St. Catherine's Indian Day School (see your letter 3-11-43, May 17/43). So far, these have not been erected owing to the difficulty in obtaining suitable pipe but it is hoped we will have them completed by the time school reopens.

When I was at this school a few days ago I had a good check-up made on the old swings and it was found that the timbers, above ground, are quite good and, by cutting off the rotten portions of the uprights and braces, we would still have two sets of swings suitable for one room schools.

I therefore recommend that we move one set of four swings to the Koksilah Indian Day School and have them properly set up. The other set of six swings to be moved to the Nanaimo Indian Day School and set up.

I received a quotation to do both jobs and am submitting same, in duplicate, for your consideration.

I believe we can do this work much cheaper than if we erected new swings at both the Koksilah and Nanaimo Indian Day Schools -- which will have to be done as there is no playground equipment at either school.

In reply to yours of the 18th instant re the old swings at St. Catherine's Indian Day School, you will please remember our discussing the moving of these old swings last Saturday, at the school, and my explanation.

1) As stated before, the posts of the swings are rotten below the ground and unsafe.

2) As these swings are in one set of 4 and one set of 6 it is only sensible to move the entire set.

3) I do not think the estimated cost of moving these exorbitant, when we consider the amount of work that has to be done.

4) As there is no other play-ground equipment at either the Nanaimo, or Koksilah Indian Day Schools, I feel that the swings asked for are not too many for this reason.

To the Fire Marshal:

Re: Inspection
St. Catherine's Indian Day School
Duncan, B.C.

As instructed by you, an inspection was made of this school on January 26, 1949. This is a two storey frame building containing four rooms and a non-standard furnace room in the basement and four classrooms on the main floor. The furnace is located directly under the main hallways and adjacent to the fire escape rear doors of the building. Should an emergency arise there the available means of egress from all of the rooms would be effectively cut off. First aid fire fighting equipment is 2 - 2½ gallon soda and acid extinguishers located one on each floor.

It is recommended that the following changes and additions be carried out to afford reasonable safety to life and property:

1. Install a standard fire alarm system comprising one 10" vibration gong and break glass switch on the upper floor and one 10 inch vibration gong and break glass switch on the lower floor, located so as to be audible to the four classrooms on each floor.

2. Install a standard furnace chamber as described in Regulation of the Chimney Regulations.

3. Install a CO₂ extinguisher in the Domestic Science Classroom. Install a 5 gallon water pump can on each floor.

4. The smoke pipe which at present passes from the Domestic Science Classroom through a partition into the furnace room to be insulated and protected as required by Regulation 22 of the Chimney Regulations.

5. Install a secondary exit from each of the classrooms at the ends of the building. The exits from two classrooms combined to allow a single stairway to grade from each of the rooms.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

HKJ/JW

C. to W.S. Arnell
Indian Commissioner For
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver

Mr. W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Post Office Box 70,
VANCOUVER, B. C.

Re: Fire Alarm System - St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

Kindly refer to your above mentioned letter relative to the subject matter stated.

I discussed this question at some length with the Proprietor of the Electrical Firm which has given me the quotation and now I am in more of a quandary than ever.

If you can recall the plan of this school you will remember that, to get out of the building, it means that the pupils will have to come out of the class-rooms to the hall immediately over the top of the furnace room (where any fire might be expected to start) then down the short flight of stairs to the entrances at either side of the school. This would mean, of course, that the children would have to walk through the very worst part of the fire as the flames would, naturally, be forced out each side door of the furnace room and up the stairways -- blocking both exits.

In considering this matter I am inclined to believe that the Alarm System might be satisfactory -- providing fire-proof doors were installed at either side of the furnace room which, if kept closed during school hours, would confine any fire originating in the furnace room to remain there long enough to allow the pupils to get out of the building. In other words, install fire-proof doors at the same time the Alarm System is put in.

As this suggestion is simply an idea of my own I should not like to say that it would be sound without getting an opinion from the Engineering Branch which was responsible for the construction -- but not the plan -- of the school.

You will note that the quotation for the Alarm System totals approximately sixty-five dollars ($65.00). Your observations to the foregoing will be appreciated.

R. H. MOORE
Supt., Cowichan Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, September 9, 1949.

Re: St. Catherine's Indian Day School,
Cowichan Indian Agency, B.C.

With reference to Major MacKay's memorandum of August 12th which bears your marginal notation of the 15th instant in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

The policy governing the design of this building allowed no provision for the installation of inside toilets then or at any future time, as existing arrangements were considered to be satisfactory.

As a consequence, major structural alterations to the building would be required in order to install the necessary toilets on the first floor, which is the most desirable location.

It is quite a different matter to make changes in a layout as was done at the Mount Elgin School during construction, to what would be necessary in this case.

If the toilets were installed in the basement, valuable space would have to be taken from assigned academical areas and it can be safely assumed that a sewage pump and sump pit would be necessary, in addition to the provision of a sewage disposal field.

If this school had been in an area served by sewers and water mains, such a pumping installation might not be required, depending of course on the relationship of the basement floor slab to the sewers. No matter how the installation were handled, it can be stated that the work could not be done without extensive structural changes; and that such operations would not be economical.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Kindly refer to your letter of above date and file authorising certain sums of money to be used to provide hot drinks during the winter months at our Day Schools in this Agency. I regret to advise that I overlooked applying again this year for the usual grants for this purpose, and took the liberty of informing some of the schools a few days ago that they might figure on the same amounts as previously. I hope that my action may be condoned and official approval given.

I am having my troubles with the Rev. Sister Sheila at St. Catherine's who is continually after me about getting the amount of $10.00 doubled for her school, the reason being that the present amount is considered totally inadequate for the number of pupils in attendance, almost 90 now and expectations of 120 to 130 later on, likely next month when the children return to their reserve with their parents from fishing, canneries and the U.S.

The Agency Nurse, Miss Fletcher, has also requested on several occasions that the actual supplies—which the amount granted buys—should be doubled if any good is expected to accrue to the children. I showed her your letter written last year which I felt would explain, better than I, the policy of the Department. However, she came back at me with a new argument, which I had not thought of before, and is this: Some of the children attending this school have to leave home about 7.30 a.m., to be in time to catch the bus as they have to walk a couple of miles, occasionally they don't get up in time to have a lunch prepared at home and go without, while others who don't have to leave so early often go without lunches too due to laziness on the part of the parents to put it up. MEMORANDUM

Re: St. Catherine's (Cowichan Agency)
Indian Day School near Duncan, B.C.

Our attention has been drawn to your notation of the 11th instant on the memorandum dated October 7th last from the Director of Indian Affairs, to which no reply has yet been furnished.

We received from Indian Commissioner Arneil as requested, a copy of the regulations governing the construction of chimneys, furnace chambers, smoke pipes etc., mentioned in our memorandum of April 4th last, to which a fire marshal's officer made reference in his report following an inspection he carried out in January, 1949.

The four roomed one storey and basement school was completed in December, 1939, from the design prepared by our architectural personnel, and standard construction practice was employed. Comment now advanced by the fire marshal covered by Sections 22 and 26 of the B.C. Fire Marshals Act, is to the effect that:

(a) The furnace room walls should be of brick or concrete construction or alternatively of laminated plank construction, covered with 1/2" of plaster on metal lath each side.

(b) A smoke pipe from the domestic science room range now carried through the existing partition, requires additional insulating covering.

Additional comment advanced but not covered by the regulations referred to, was as follows:

(c) Electrically operated fire alarm system with vibrating gongs and break glass switches, should be installed at each floor level, located so as to be audible to all classrooms.

(d) An extra fire extinguisher should be installed in the domestic science classroom and a 5 gallon water pump and container should be placed in a convenient position on each floor.

(e) Secondary exits from groups of two classrooms with stairs to grade for each, should be installed.

Following receipt of the data we requested from Indian Commissioner Arneil, the fire marshal's remarks were discussed with Col. Neary of the Indian Affairs and the following comment furnished. The items are dealt with in the same order as above.

(a) To construct furnace chamber walls to conform to B.C. standards in place of the existing walls built of 2 x 4 studing sheet each side with 7/8" shiplap and 1/4" gypsum board, would be expensive and inconvenient, but could be carried out without major alterations to the building, preferably during a holiday period at a cost of approximately $1,000.00.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
We assume that the fire marshal's comment regarding the smoke pipe from the domestic science room, is coupled with his objection to the nature of the furnace chamber walls and the cost of rectifying would be negligible.

(c) The installation of a fire signal system is a necessity. This was not included in the original design since wiring was not to have been installed. Wiring for lighting and water supply only, was requested by Indian Affairs as an addition to the contract during construction operations and no alarm signal was requested at that time. Indian Affairs were furnished by the local Superintendent, with an estimate for installing this unit amounting to approximately $75.00.

(d) The supply of additional fire extinguishers and water pump with container are items that Indian Affairs will handle as supply maintenance.

(e) There is no inexpensive way of providing additional exits from the main floor classrooms for this building. The design approved by Dr. McGill then Director of Indian Affairs placed the furnace room in the centre of the basement, the only position from which satisfactory hot air distribution to the classrooms could be made. Two sets of stairs were provided, one at each side of the building, easily accessible to all classrooms and by means of which all pupils in the school could be evacuated quickly and safely.

The basement rooms are only occupied periodically however, when certain groups of pupils are receiving manual training or domestic science instruction. The upper floor pupilage is reduced by approximately 50% at those times. Basement windows are only 30" from the floor with sills practically at grade level. These with the stairs provide ample escape routes in an emergency. All the upper classroom window sills are only 91½" from the ground. There is little likelihood of both sets of stairs being cut off at the same time in case of fire, and it is felt that if a 6 foot step-ladder was made available for each classroom, evacuation of all pupils could be safely effected.

To carry out the fire marshal's suggestion to provide additional exits and stairs, would necessitate extensive structural alterations and would cost in the neighborhood of $2,000.00.

When the report was discussed after receiving the Provincial regulations, both Col. Neary and Mr. Buck, while recognizing that the letter of these regulations had not been followed, formed the opinion that there was no cause for alarm and with the exception of providing the fire signal system, adding the recommended number of extinguishers and providing ladders, no drastic action was necessary.

In a telephone conversation with Col. Neary this morning, that officer stated he had not yet discussed the matter with his Director and would do so on receipt of this memorandum and advise us of the action Indian Affairs wished to have taken.

Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

Please find attached a copy of the report which has been received from the Lands and Development Services Branch with regard to the fire marshal's report made on this school.

I believe Inspector Davey will agree with me when I say there are many provincial schools in which conditions are much worse than at St. Catherine's. I feel that if we provide the following items we will be providing sufficient to meet our requirements at this school. Naturally, if this were a residential school, we would be prepared to meet the other requirements.

(a) Fire alarm system.
(b) Extra fire extinguishers.
(c) Secondary exits in the form of ladders.
(d) Additional insulation for smoke pipe from Domestic Science range.

Bernard F. Neary,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Citizenship and Immigration, Ottawa, Canada.

Attached is our voucher #494 of today's date, made payable to the Cowichan Motor Transport (Kyle) Ltd., in the amount of $436.30, covering transportation of Indian children from the Somenos Village to St. Catherine's Indian Day School during the months of January and February, 1950.

The Department will please note that during the month of February it was necessary for the bus to take a detour for seven days on account of road blocks caused by the extremely heavy snowfall we experienced here this past winter. Additional mileage each day was eight miles; and the Company has made an extra charge of 40¢ per day. Under the circumstances this is quite reasonable.

In addition to the above, restrictions were placed on load limits on buses and trucks during the thawing period in order to reduce breaking up of the roads as much as possible. In order to keep within these restrictions it was necessary for the Company to run a taxi as well as their bus for several days during the month of February. Their taxi account for this period is less than had they charged for the usual overload.

I would recommend that the account be paid as submitted.

Dear Sir;

Following our verbal discussion in regard to our tendering for the bus service on your Indian School and following the general outline as laid down by you. We hereby tender for the above route in the following manner.

Our route in the morning would be leaving the Somonos Reserve on the Highway at the White Bridge, then northerly to Trunk Road, easterly on Trunk Road to St. Catherines School. Continuing on Trunk Road to the intersection of Trunk Rd., and alternate No. 1 Highway (Tennis Court Corner) thence westerly on alternate No. 1 Highway to Highway intersection of Highway No. 1 to Koksalah Indian Mission Road. Easterly along the Indian Mission Road to the Mission School. Turning at this point and reversing direction of travel over route, dropping children at St., Catherines School and return to Duncan. The routing in the afternoon would be the same as in the morning to take the Children home.

Mileage to be operated on the above mentioned route would amount to 32 miles per day, at a daily cost to your Department of $16.00 per school day operated.

To provide this service we would provide a Coach with a carrying capacity of 45 pupils from grades 1-7 and 35 pupils from grades 8-12 or a number of both worked out on this basis.

Our schedule will be worked out with the approval of yourself and schools concerned to give the most satisfactory results in getting the pupils to school and home as promptly as possible.

RE: Your file #152/6-1-807, June 1, 1950.

With reference to your letter above mentioned and previous correspondence relative to unsatisfactory operation of the electric pump and water system at St. Catherine's Indian Day School, I would advise that a few days ago we managed to locate the cause of the air leakage in the tank and the almost constant running of the electric pump. This was found to be a loose connection of the stand pipe outside the wellhouse proper, and which is used by the children to drink from during play hours or recess hours.

I had a plumber go out and investigate, and after some discussion we decided that the best thing to do would be to take out the stand pipe entirely and install three drinking fountains, two within and one outside the school building.

The attached quotation in duplicate covering the cost of these, plus labour, comes to $102.59.

From the point of view of sanitation, these are much better than the old tin cups that the children have been using for the past several years, and I would recommend that the quotation submitted be accepted and the expenditure approved.

Dear Sir:

With reference to Inspector Barry's report regarding his inspection of the Cowichan R.C. Day School on March 24 the Department approves your purchasing a set of tools as recommended by the Inspector. He states that these can be secured for $25.00 and no doubt you can choose the tools in Vancouver and have them shipped to the school.

An expenditure of $15.00 may also be incurred for the purchase of lumber for the manual training class.

Inspector Barry also suggests employing an Indian woman for one hour a week to instruct the girls in carding and preparation of wool which could be knit into Cowichan sweaters. Provided a capable woman can be secured at a cost of $1.00 a week as suggested by Inspector Barry you may authorize the Indian Agent to make the necessary arrangements.

From time to time the Department authorizes small quantities of lumber for manual training purposes. Would it be possible to secure used packing cases. The material in such cases could well be used at the day schools at least. It would mean less expenditure and probably mean that more lumber would be available. Please let me know if you consider the suggestion feasible.

Extract from Inspector Barry's report of March 24, 1938:

Vocational Training:

I have explained in detail what is required for the forthcoming Arts and Crafts Exhibition in Vancouver. The teacher wishes to be informed on a number of points and these were explained. The school will send a small exhibit.

I would recommend that a good single set of tools for woodwork and not to exceed a cost of $25.00 be authorized for this school. Some lumber material not to exceed $15.00 would also be required. The teacher can instruct in simple Manual Training and there are a number of repairs now very necessary at the school, steps to front doors and cupboards in the halls, etc., which the boys could undertake if they had some tools, which will otherwise cost the Department just as much or more if carried out in any other manner.

I particularly wish to see this Simple Manual Work introduced here.

I would also recommend that an Indian woman be employed two afternoons in the week for one hour each time to instruct in carding and preparation of local wool, which the girls could knit into Cowichan Sweaters etc. under her direction. A sum of $1.00 per week would not be excessive and this would not amount to more than $35.00 per year. This money would in my opinion be well spent in the starting of Vocational Training in this school.

The local Missionary the Rev. Father Lauzon discussed this matter of the establishment of some work in Manual Training under the present teacher, and of the teaching of the girls to prepare wool and knit Cowichan Sweaters etc., and stated that he could no doubt suggest a suitable woman. He seemed anxious to have this sort of work started in the Cowishan Indian Day School as it had proved so successful in the other local Indian Day School at Koksilah.

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to Departmental letter No. 152-8-11 of the 12th instant, in paragraph 4 of which Mr. R. A. Hoey suggests the possible use of old packing cases where lumber for Manual Training is required in Indian Day Schools, would say that in British Columbia packing cases of any large size cannot be obtained free from the stores, but must be purchased. The cost is usually well in excess of that of the lumber from which they are made.

In addition I may say that most of the packing cases coming to this Province are constructed from different kinds of white wood, which is very soft and useless for Manual Training purposes.

In the instances where I have recommended the supply of small quantities of lumber for Indian Day Schools, I have intended that this should be ordinary fir, which in the rough state and in short lengths can be purchased for around $15.00 per M.

Under the circumstances, I cannot possibly recommend the purchase of packing cases, as suggested by the Superintendent of Welfare and Training.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your air mail letter of September 30 in which you state that a requisition for pots and other cooking utensils necessary at the Ste. Catherine's Indian Day School was forwarded by you under date of March 12 last.

Immediately following receipt of your communication a thorough search was made of the files here in an attempt to find, if possible, the requisition referred to in your communication. I regret to state, however, that we have not succeeded in discovering the requisition or any evidence that would indicate that it ever reached this office. In our letter of March 18 to which you refer it was noted that the requisition was coming forward but there is nothing to indicate that it arrived. It is just possible that this requisition was lost in the train wreck that took place about that date.

In view of the urgency of the matter and the delay that has already taken place would you please forward the requisition to Commissioner MacKay and have him make the necessary purchases. I am sending forward a copy of this letter to the Commissioner for his information and guidance.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. R. H. Moore,

Duncan, B.C.
Sir:

Under date of March 12th, last, a requisition was forwarded under cover of letter from this office, in connection with the pots and other cooking utensils required for the domestic science class at the Ste. Catherine's Indian Day School, but to date no authority has come to hand covering the purchase.

Reverend Sister Mary Armella the principal of the school advises that the purchase of same is absolutely necessary to carry on the domestic science class.

In your letter of March 15th, last you authorized an expenditure of $5.00 per month for supplies required for the domestic science class, and in the last paragraph of this letter, you note that a requisition was coming forward for the necessary pots and other cooking utensils, and as mentioned above this requisition went forward under cover of letter dated March 12th.

Yours obediently,

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith in duplicate a letter recently received from the Principal of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School asking that a Spinning wheel and Carding machine for wool be procured for the use of the handicraft class at this School.

Apparently this matter has been discussed with yourself, and Inspector Barry, previously by the Rev. Sister Mary Armella and you are both fully conversant with the requirements of the school as well as the work which they have been doing at the school during the past and present term, so that it is unnecessary for me to elaborate on the matter to any extent.

It is quite true that more work can be done by the use of the carding machine than by carders and the actual cost is less when the requirements of the school are taken into consideration. On the other hand I have heard that better carding can be done by hand than with the machine, although I must confess that I have never seen a carder as efficient looking as the one shown in the attached price list, or catalogue sheet, as put out by the "Spin-well Woolen Mills Co., Ltd., of Sifton Manitoba," so that it is quite possible that the carding machine is essential for good results in an institution of this kind. The Spinning machine of course is definitely needed.

If the Department would approve of these articles I feel that it would be a step in the right direction.

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Yours obediently,

(R.H. Moore)

Dear Mr. Moore:

As you have personally observed, we have seriously begun the Indian knitting industry. We are handicapped, however, in not having the necessary equipment towards a successful issue of said industry. Indian Commissioner, Major D.M. MacKay, as well as School Inspector, Captain G.H. Barry have suggested that we requisition a spinning machine from the Department.

If you consider it feasible, we should appreciate your asking the Department for a carding and a spinning machine. We are requesting a carding machine instead of carders because six pairs of carders would be necessary for this school, and the small difference in price is not worth the strenuous work involved in the use of carders. Several Indian families are using carding machines which are proving most satisfactory. One Indian mother told us that it took her, her husband and three children two days to card the same amount of wool by hand that she carded alone in one hour on the carding machine.

Upon inquiry, we find that a spinning machine can be purchased from an Indian for ten dollars ($10), but it is crude, while for the same price a modern spinning machine can be bought.
Enclose please find advertisement for the two machines which we think would serve the purpose.

Trusting to receive a favorable reply,

I remain,

Very sincerely yours,

Sister Mary Arnolda

Principal.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant enclosing requisition for manual training tools and other equipment for use at the St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

In reviewing the June quarter return of this school it was found that there was only 1 boy in Grade 7 and 7 boys in Grade 4. No boys were shown in either Grades 5 or 6. A careful study of the manual training supplies previously placed in this school indicates that they should have all the supplies required, especially in view of the very small number of boys who are capable of benefiting by this instruction.

Dear Sir:

Re St. Catherine's Indian School

An application has been received from Mr. Indian Agent Moore for Manual Training equipment and garden tools for the marginally noted school. Quotations have been received from local sources of supply and these have been summarized by Inspector Barry whose letters of October 9th in this connection are attached hereto.

It will be observed that Inspector Barry suggests the deletion of wardrobe hooks, rafter square and bench vise from the list of Manual Training equipment, and the lawnmower from the list of garden tools applied for. I should think that a bench vise and rafter square could be used to very good advantage in the Manual Training Division. The wardrobe hooks are probably required in the school for cupboard and locker accommodation used for books and various kinds of equipment. Purchase of the lawnmower could, of course, be deferred until the Spring. Otherwise the applications appear in order and supply recommended if funds are available.

Yours faithfully,

With reference to requisitions of the 23rd ultimo you may purchase the articles shown on the attached requisitions for the use of the domestic science class at the St. Catherine's Day School.

Dear Mr. Moore:

The spinning machine now in use at St. Catherine's School spins much too fine for the Cowichan Indian knitting and therefore we do not get the best results.

When Major Mackay visited the school last November he noted that both the spinner and the carder were too small for the amount of work done. He told us to requisition a larger one of each.

We now have the opportunity of an Indian made machine, made by Mr. Georgson of Koksilah, complete for ($12) twelve dollars. We have had one in the school on trial for a couple of weeks and it has proved very satisfactory.

Would you kindly requisition this from the Department for us, Mr. Moore?

Thanking you and hoping for a favourable reply I am,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Sir:

I beg to attach hereto a letter in duplicate which I have just received from the Principle of St. Catherine's Indian Day School regarding the possibility of procuring a larger spinning machine and carder for use at the above mentioned school. You will please note that it will be possible to procure an Indian made spinning machine made from an old sewing machine frame for the sum of $12.00.

I have also located a much larger carding machine which I can get for the same price, viz.: $12.00.

This latter machine is at present owned by Mrs. Edmond Underwood of the Saanich Reserve and it cost $17.00 about a year and a half ago and is really a first-class machine and in first-class repair.

I recommend that I have the authority to procure both these machines at the price mentioned.

Yours very truly,

Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 1st instant, with reference to a request that you have received for additional tools and material for vocational training purposes at the St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

We have carefully reviewed the information that we have on file regarding the tools already supplied and, for your information, I enclose a list showing the tools purchased for this school since 1938. It is evident from the list supplied by the teacher that many of these tools are missing. Possibly some of them have become useless owing to use, but at the same time it is felt that there are more missing than there should be.

In continuing the vocational training class at this school it is essential to have the necessary tools in order that the teacher may give proper instruction. With this admitted we feel that additional tools are necessary and the purchase of the attached list of tools and materials is authorized. With the supplying of these tools together with those already in the school there should be an adequate supply on hand for all practical purposes.

We are not authorizing the No. 45 Stanley plane. This is a difficult plane to handle and the only practical necessity for it would be for grooving. A grooving plane is much easier to handle but, as far as we are aware, cannot be secured at the present time and, therefore, this item should be dropped.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of the 13th of February; copy of my letter of the 26th of February, and Mr. Moore's letter of the 24th ultimo, together with requisition for manual training tools and material for the St. Catherine's Indian Day School, and an inventory of the tools now on hand.

I would advise that in the absence of a Departmental School Inspector, I have no information as to the tool requirements for the average of 10 pupils taking this instruction at the school, but it will be noted that the cost of the items in the requisition will probably be in the neighbourhood of $200.00 and until there is some assurance that the attendance of this school will be maintained at a satisfactory level I hesitate to recommend approval of the application, apart from the question as to whether the additional tools would be necessary in any event.

The school was recently inspected by Provincial Inspector Plenderleith whose reports are enclosed herewith, but are, in my opinion valueless as they merely reflect the opinion of the Indian Agent and the school staff, giving virtually no detail of the achievements of the pupils.

In view of the question that arose a short time ago in respect to pupils of this school having to go to Koksilah Day school to prepare for High School entrance examination, at which time it was stated by the Reverend Principal of St. Catherine's that the curriculum set up by Mr. Inspector Barry did not permit of such preparation, it was hoped that the Provincial Inspector would have been able to have reviewed the curriculum now in use and made some definite recommendation on

P.T.O.
I beg to submit herewith in duplicate two requisitions submitted by the Principal of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School for manual training supplies and tools for the manual training division of the school.

Quotations were asked for and received from the local representative of Marshall-Wells Co., but you will note that there were several items which he would not quote on. You will also please note that the drawing equipment asked for is for use in the manual training room as well as the blackboards.

I find that the present Manual training instructor is very well qualified, and with proper and sufficient tools with which he can make more necessary equipment for class rooms and manual training room, his usefulness to the school generally will be greatly increased. For instance, work benches are badly required and with the proper tools these can be made right in the class room by the boys.

I would recommend that favourable consideration be given these requests.

(R.M. Moore)
Indian Agent.
February 26th, 1943.

R.H. Moore, Esq., Indian Agent, Duncan, B.C.

Replying to your letter of the 13th instant enclosing requisitions for tools etc., for the manual training division of St. Catherine's Indian Day School, I would advise that it is noted that the quantity on hand of some of these tools is shown by an X which it is presumed means "nil".

On checking over the files it is found that Purchase Orders, including tools in the items, were issued as follows:

| No.   | Date          |
|-------|--------------|
| 26598 | June 12th, 1940 |
| 29907 | Oct. 31st, 1940 |
| 29972 | Jan. 15th, 1941 |
| 2953  | Nov. 4th, 1941 |
| 7674  | June 30th, 1942 |

and I would also refer to my letter of January 14th, 1942 re Chisels and disapproval of the purchase of Stanley Plane, the latter item being again included in your requisition despite the fact that the Department has previously refused to consider the item.

In view of the fact that the Department previously questioned the supply of further manual training tools for the school, due to the low attendance, and that many of the tools already supplied did not appear to be on hand, I would request that you go over the Purchase Orders above mentioned and make up an inventory in quadruplicate which should also include the garden tools for outside use and those for the Janitor. You should then have these checked at the school and copy left with the Reverend Principal covering the tools actually on hand, another kept in your office, the other two being forwarded to this office in duplicate giving an explanation for the shortages, if any. On receipt of this inventory, together with a statement of the average number of pupils in attendance to be given manual training tuition, I will then take up the matter with the Department.

p.t.o.
Indian Commissioner for B.C. P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

In reply to your letter above noted, wherein you returned certain requisitions for additional tools for St. Catherine's Indian Day School Manual Training Division, I beg to submit herewith in duplicate—as requested—a complete list of all tools purchased for this school since it was opened, with a list of the Purchase Orders issued and the number of the Vouchers in payment of same submitted from this Office.

In many instances you will note that P.O.'s covered supplies as well as tools; naturally the supplies are not listed as they have been used or are in the process of being used, in various articles being made for use at the school. You are quite correct in your assumption that the "X" shown on the form as being on hand, means "Nil".

I am quite well aware that the Department did not approve of the purchase of a Stanley Plane previously, but certain work is being expected of the Manual Training Instructor which it is not possible for him to do unless he has the proper tools, and I venture the opinion that if Inspector Barry had not recommended against the purchase of this article of equipment in the first place the Department would not have objected. However, if you will not recommend that it be procured please delete it from this requisition. I have mentioned many many times, the principal cause of the poor attendance at this school, viz: the lack of a Truant Officer, and until one is made available the attendance will always be unsatisfactory.

I attach herewith a letter which I have received from the Principal which I hope will be found self-explanatory. If the tools asked for are supplied we may be able to have the squares, triangles and drawing boards constructed as you suggest. Requisitions are being returned herewith for your further consideration.

(R.H.Moore)
Indian Agent.

REPORT ON COWICHAN INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1944

As reported last month a meeting was held with the Chiefs of the Cowichan Band in regard to the then irregular attendance at St. Catherine's school, the outcome being that a meeting of the Teacher's of the School and the Councils was arranged when the matter was fully discussed and all phases of the school and the program of studies gone into and explained by the Teachers. Ottawa, March 29, 1945.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to Inspector Plenderleith's report on his inspection of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

In regard to the second paragraph of your letter, I may say that the sewing machine promised last year was shipped to the school and reached there early in July of 1944.

Regarding science equipment, the Department approves an expenditure of approximately $20.00. This is the same amount as was allowed at the Tsartlip School. In connection with supplying science equipment to the Tsartlip School, I would refer you to the second paragraph of my letter of December 7, 1944, at which time we authorized the purchase of science equipment at Tsartlip.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Inspector Plenderleith's reports covering his inspection of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School which he visited on February 12th.

With reference to the Inspector's recommendation regarding the supply of another sewing machine, I would refer you to Mr. Indian Agent Moore's requisition of April 29th for two Singer sewing machines and the Department's letter of May 27, 1944, file 152-22-11, wherein you advised that it had been decided to order one sewing machine for the school. Our records do not indicate whether this machine was supplied or not.

The supply of science equipment to the St. Catherine's School has been the subject of previous correspondence, your letter of May 30, 1944, stating that "careful consideration has been given to the request of the teacher for this equipment but the Department does not consider it advisable to supply it at the present time". It would be appreciated if you would advise if the Department's policy in this connection has been changed in view of the fact that similar equipment was recently supplied to the Tsartlip School.

(Sgd.) James Coleman,
for D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

In reply to your letter above noted, I wish to advise that a new sewing machine was supplied to the St. Catherine's Indian Day School last year and the Inspector was so advised, but stated that three machines were not enough for a class of 16 present at that time. I am informed that there are actually 22 girls in attendance at that school who are capable of using machines. Naturally another machine would make the work of teaching sewing a lot easier, but the school can get along without one.

(R.H. Moore)

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of March 29th (File 152-22-11) in connection with Inspector Plenderleith's report on his inspection of the St. Catherine's Indian Day School, and in particular to the proposed supply of another sewing machine, I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of April 17th, from which it will be noted that there are now three machines at the school and that there are actually 22 girls in attendance who are capable of using machines.

In reviewing the Inspector's report it is noted that there was a total of 26 pupils in Grades 4 to 7 inclusive, 19 of whom were present, and presuming that one-half the enrolment are boys, there would be only 13 pupils to use the three machines now at the school. I could not, therefore, recommend the supply of another sewing machine until such time as the pupilage warrants such action.

Ottawa, June 27, 1945.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant, you may purchase the supplies required for the manual training class at the St. Catherine's Indian Day School, with the exception of the Yale latches and the rules. The Department agrees with your statement, that serviceable articles could be secured at a much lower price.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's requisition of April 27th, 1945, for manual training material amounting to about $39.10 for St. Catherine's Indian Day School, together with a copy of my enquiry of the 14th ultimo to Mr. Moore and his reply of the 18th instant.

It appears to me that the method of fastening the cupboards with a yale night latch at a cost of $3.50 each is somewhat more expensive than is necessary, and in the absence of information as to whether the supplies are to be used for manual training purposes it is open to question whether this item would be a proper charge against the B.C. Special Vote. Notwithstanding Agent Moore's remarks, I am still of the opinion that the more expensive fold rules are not satisfactory for a manual training class and the children do not have to carry these rules around in their pocket. Furthermore, as you are aware, they are extremely liable to break at the joints.

Subject to the foregoing, I would recommend approval of the application.

D.M. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Further information is required in connection with a number of items listed on your Requisition of April 27th for manual training supplies and equipment for the St. Catherine's Indian Day School, as we wish to be sure that all items are a proper charge against the B.C. Special Vote and will not be used for maintenance of the school building. Please advise what use is to be made of the two Yale night latches, six cupboard locks, one set of ball-bearing castors and 2 doz. chair glides.

I may say that I have some doubt as to the wisdom of supplying 2 ft. 4-fold rules as there would be more of a tendency to misplace these articles than there would a yard-stick or rigid rule of some kind.

You might let me have your comments on this point.

For D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.

-HN
Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver,

In reference to your above noted letters I wish to advise as follows:

1. Yale night Latches for storage cupboards for supplies.
2. Six cupboard locks for domestic science kitchen supply cupboards, recently built.
3. Chides for chairs made in school by pupils and for use there.
4. For service waggon for serving cocoa and collecting dirty dishes. (castors)
5. There has only been one rule misplaced since the school was built; the yard stick you suggest is too unhandy and would be broken within a week.

Personally, I have never seen a carpenter going round with a three foot rigid rule or yard stick, and I believe it would be a mistake to supply them to a manual training room.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I am enclosing herewith a requisition dated May 1st for domestic science equipment for the St. Catherine's Indian Day School at an approximate cost of $100.00.

Various items of such equipment were supplied to this school last year and it is considered that if the items listed were secured the domestic science division should be well equipped insofar as this type of equipment is concerned for some time to come. I would recommend that authority be granted for local purchase of the articles asked for.

Enc.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Memorandum
To: Indian Commissioner
From: School Inspector

Re: Manual Training
St. Catherine's School.

At the time of my inspection of the St. Catherine's School on January 20th and 21st, last I was not entirely satisfied with the type of work being done in the manual training classes. At that time I made certain suggestions to Mr. Morrison which he was to follow. I shall visit this school the next time I go to the Island and see if these suggestions have been carried out.

Concerning the suggestion in the Cowichan Band Resolution that the pupils engage in drawing plans for buildings, I recommended at the time of my visit that a certain amount of elementary constructional drawing be given, but these pupils are not ready to undertake anything as ambitious as the resolution proposes.

R.F. Davey,
District Inspector of Indian Schools.
Major D. H. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Post Office Box 70,
VANCOUVER, B. C.

I beg to attach, herewith, in duplicate, a Resolution from the Cowichan Band Council relative to a suggested change in the type of instructions which are being given to the children taking the manual training instruction at St. Catherine's Indian School.

This matter has been the subject of correspondence and recommendations from this office on several occasions as well as having discussed the question with Major Davey, who, no doubt, will give the matter attention during his next inspection of the school.

R. H. Moore
Indian Agent.

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, July 10th, 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, the Department approves an expenditure of approximately $180 covering the cost of manual training tools and equipment for the St. Catherine's School. When forwarding accounts you should mark on them "Pay from B.C. Special".

The Department is not prepared to supply the rangette and the sewing machine at the present time as we feel that the home economics department is well equipped.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I am enclosing a requisition dated May 1st covering the proposed supply of an electric range and a Singer sewing machine for the St. Catherine's Indian Day School, together with a memorandum dated June 30th from School Inspector Davey in this connection.

You will note that Mr. Davey considers the Home Economics Department of this school to be better equipped than any three-roomed Provincial school in British Columbia, and that in his opinion priority in the matter of the supply of such equipment should be given to other schools at the present time.

I am inclined to agree with the School Inspector in this connection and I suggest that the requisition be held in abeyance until it is known to what extent the present Home Economics facilities at the school will provide for the enrolment next September.

A copy of the other requisitions referred to by Mr. Davey covering the supply of Manual Training tools and equipment for St. Catherine's school, at an approximate cost of $150.00 is attached hereto and I would recommend that authority be granted to purchase the items from the best source available.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

enclos.
MEMORANDUM

TO: Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver, B.C.,
FROM: Inspector of Indian Schools. June 30th, 1947.

Re: Requisitions for Vocational Training,
St. Catherine's Indian Day School.

I am not prepared to recommend the installation of an electric range at the above-mentioned School nor the Reversew Singer Sewing Machine.

The Home Economics Department of this School is at present better equipped than any three-room school that I know either Indian or White in this Province. It is felt that the expenditure of this money, when supplies and equipment are badly needed at other Schools, is not justified.

With regard to the item "10 prs. Triangles, Zylonite" for the manual training Department, I suggest that wooden ones would be considerably cheaper and serve the purpose just as well. The other items on the Requisitions seem to be in order.

R. F. Davey,
Dist. Inspector of Indian Schools.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I am very pleased to hear from you concerning the domestic science department. It is encouraging to know that you understand the problems we are facing.

The point you raise is one which was widely discussed with Major Davey, our School Inspector, on the occasion of his first visit to our school.

For reasons, which now seem clear to you, I strongly supported full time domestic science and manual training teachers so that there could be a proportionate integration of the above, with straight academic and other school activities.

Major Davey was given orders this time last year to cut down the manual training instructor's time. (I do not know on whose orders but these letters must be on your files.) Therefore the domestic science had to run on the same basis. As a result the domestic science and manual training activities have been the controlling factors with regard to the whole school curriculum.

The children who are desirous of continuing high school studies need more academic teaching, while those who do not intend going further than Grade Eight benefit more by extra vocational training. Under the present regime the class teacher has no other option but to group the classes for those departments.

The integration of studies would assuredly be easier if the teachers were on full time duty.

Another point for consideration is the steadily growing attendance.
After due consideration of these facts I shall be glad to abide by your decision, and also to lay before you a detailed outline of what is essential to a well equipped domestic science department.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, November 10, 1947.

Reverend and dear Sister:

Reporting on his recent visit to the St. Catherine's Day school, Mr. Boucet of this Department writes as follows:

"It is regretted that the well equipped domestic science department was not in operation at the time of my inspection. I am of the opinion that domestic science is only taught for a few months during each academic year. I feel that it would be more preferable to integrate the domestic science with other activities and especially with the straight academic course."

While there may be special reasons for the procedure that has been followed, we feel that the method at present in use involves a great loss of the educational value which is attached to such an activity.

I, therefore, strongly recommend that the domestic science course be integrated with the academic studies. I would appreciate hearing from you that our suggestion is being put into immediate effect.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Heary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. Sr. Mary Sheila,
St. Catherine's Indian Day School,
Duncan, B.C.

I am enclosing a memorandum dated March 21st, from District School Inspector Davey, with regard to Domestic Science facilities at the St. Catherine's Day School.

You will note that consideration had previously been given to the installation of a large institutional range for the Domestic Science class, to replace the small standard range presently in use which is burned out beyond repair. It is considered by Mr. Davey, however, that it would be preferable to install two standard kitchen ranges which will necessitate the construction of an additional chimney on the west end of the present classroom.

MEMORANDUM

March 21, 1949.

Re: Stove - St. Catherine's Indian Day School

On the occasion of my recent visit to the above mentioned school I considered the possibility of installation of a large Institutional Range to replace the present kitchen stove which is being used for cooking classes.

There is no doubt that the stove of the Institutional type would give much longer service than the ordinary household range but I feel that it would be better to supply the type normally used in the home. The chief purpose of the home economics course is to try and develop among the girls a standard of housekeeping comparable to that found in the majority of white homes. We should therefore provide our Home Economics rooms with equipment of the type we wish our Indian homes to use.

For the number of pupils in the average cooking class at this school two ovens are required. I would recommend therefore that in place of a large two oven Institutional stove we provide an additional chimney on the west end of the present classroom and install two kitchen ranges.

I might add that I have checked with the supervisor of Home Economics instruction for the Provincial Schools in B.C. and she informs me that the Home Economics rooms in the majority of the Provincial schools are provided with two or three such ranges.

R.F. Davey,
District School Inspector.

We have your letter of the 13th instant enclosing a report from Inspector Davey with regard to the Domestic Science facilities at the St. Catherine's Day School. We are prepared to authorize the purchase of two stoves, provided it will not be necessary to construct a new chimney.

From experiences we have had, we have found it possible to connect two stoves to the same flue, and therefore, we cannot see why an expenditure of $209.00 is required for a new chimney.

In the third paragraph of your letter you state that two stoves would cost approximately $360.00. This seems very high as we usually supply stoves costing approximately $90.00. Approval is granted for an expenditure of $180.00 for the two stoves.

Ottawa, September 26, 1930.

Sir:

Referring to official letter dated May 9th, last, regarding the appointment of a teacher and field matron for the Babine Indian Day School, I have to inform you that His Lordship Bishop Bunoz has nominated the services of Mr. C. O. Daly as teacher and his wife as field matron. The Department is approving of these appointments from the last instant.

The salary allowed Mr. Daly will be at the rate of $90 per teaching month, and Mrs. Daly will be paid at the rate of $300 per annum. Mr. Daly possesses a first class teacher's certificate for the Province of Alberta, and has had previous teaching experience. Mrs. Daly is a trained nurse, with considerable experience. As stated in letter above referred to, it is expected that Mrs. Daly will give an average weekly service of eighteen hours. I have to request that you will give both Mr. and Mrs. Daly every assistance you can in their work.

Mr. Daly should prepare and forward a report on the forms for that purpose at the end of each quarter showing the attendance, days taught, etc., and Mrs. Daly should prepare a brief report showing the work performed by her. These should be forwarded to the Department through your office.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 18th, 1930.

Sir,

Enclosed is a letter which the Department has recently received from Mr. C. O. Daly, teacher of the Port Babine Indian Day School. You will note that his first complaint is the expense which he has to incur in order to secure his mail. Would it not be possible to arrange for delivery of his mail, say, once a week?

You will, also, note that he mentions that he has no supplies on hand. The only requisition the Department has received is one forwarded by you last month for readers, geographies, histories and arithmetics. These were forwarded on October 27th, addressed to the teacher at Topley, B. C. In view of the statement in his letter, I am today ordering from the Government Stationery Office a supply of chalk, scribblers, exercise books, lead pencils, drawing paper, blackboard brushes, ink powder, penholders and pens.

Sir,

I respectfully beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 151-5-3, dated November 16th, 1930, with enclosure from Mr. C. O. Daly, Teacher of the Indian Day School at Fort Babine. I am returning Mr. Daly's letter herewith.

I will first deal with the question of the mail service to Fort Babine. There is no mail service to Fort Babine, and the nearest Post Office is at Topley on the Canadian National Railway, about 100 miles distant. Mail is carried in to Fort Babine by Indians or white people if they are visiting Topley from that district on business. To arrange for Mr. Daly to get his mail weekly would be an expensive proposition as the return journey during the winter would take approximately a week to complete. During the summer months, mail reaches Fort Babine much more frequently owing to the fact that people are moving in and out, to and from Fort Babine almost daily.

Regarding school supplies etc., when I visited Fort Babine in August last, I inspected the Fort Babine Indian School and found all kinds of school material such as scribblers, exercise books, pencils, chalk, ink and drawing paper, in fact the School was well supplied with material, left that way by the late Teacher, Mr. Morrissey. I was pleased with everything at the School except its lack of cleanliness; the floors, desks and walls might have been cleaner, however I have since instructed Mr. Daly, by letter, to have the walls kalsomined and the School thoroughly cleaned out.

I anticipated Mr. Daly being at Fort Babine when I visited there in August, but he did not arrive until the latter part of September, 1930. Had he been at Fort Babine during my visit he would have got all information first hand. I have written several letters to Mr. Daly, but as Fort Babine is difficult of access at this time of the year, letters take considerable time to come and go.

For me to make a special visit to Fort Babine at the present time would cost considerable expense to the Department and I feel it is an unnecessary expense. However, Mr. Daly is being rendered every assistance by this Office.

Sir,

On looking up the Indian Day School Regulations I note that salaries are paid to teachers of such schools only quarterly and then only on receipt of quarterly returns.

I would like you to take into serious consideration the inconvenience and expense that such a system entails on a teacher.

Take my case for instance. I am now finishing my fifth month in Babine and all I have as yet received for my services is the September cheque for #90, which, by the way, was not issued from head office until the 18th November, if I remember rightly, and was not received by me until the 22nd December, so I had no opportunity until today of sending out the
Way school returns, and as, according to our rule, no cheque will be issued in my favour until after their receipt in Ottawa, it will probably be well into March before I receive the salary due to me for the quarter ending the 31st December; and then another month will probably elapse before I get a chance of sending my cheque out to get it cashed. This means that I am compelled to endeavour to support a family for six or probably seven months on the paltry sum of $70, or $120 if the $30 received by my wife in December is included. As a result both my life insurance policies lapsed. I issued promissory notes to pay the premiums, plus interest, of course, on the 28th January, making sure that I would have received my salary by then but alas! now I have not a cent to meet the matured notes.

Besides all this the lack of ready money, which would not often if our salaries were paid monthly, has compelled my family and myself to do without many things, clothes, etc., which we really ought to have had this winter.

Under these circumstances can you blame me for characterising this quarterly salary system as not only antiquated but positively unjust and
No firm or corporation, and probably very few government departments, would dream of inflicting such a ghastly anachronism on their employees nowadays.

This is merely a plain statement of fact and I hope that my plea in favour of monthly salaries will receive from your department the sympathetic attention that it undoubtedly deserves. Even in settled communities, in the light of modern economic conditions a monthly salary is a sharp necessity; but it is only one who has lived in the wilds can really form an adequate idea of what a boon and a blessing a monthly salary would confer on people, far from the outposts of civilization who are, to say the least, forced to undergo many privations of a vexatious nature at the best of times.

Your truly,

Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 157-7-3, dated February 26th, 1931 referring to mail facilities for the benefit of the Indian Bay School Teacher and the Field Matron of Fort Babine, I respectfully beg to report that I have made careful enquiries as to what possible means by which mail could be forwarded to the above mentioned parties.

I interviewed the Inspector of Dominion Fisheries at this point and he informs me that the Dominion Fish Hatcheries secure their mail once per month, but that the Fish Hatcheries are quite distant from Fort Babine and, therefore, their letter carrier would be obliged to go many miles off his route in order to deliver mail to Fort Babine.

The only logical way for mail to be shipped to this point is by the Hudson's Bay Co.'s carrier from Toplay Station, which is also monthly. This system has been in operation for many years and apparently was satisfactory to both the Hudson's Bay Company and the late Indian Bay School Teacher, Mr. Morley. During my visit, I was able to speak to Mr. Morley regarding mail facilities to Fort Babine in winter time and he informed me that he had been receiving his mail, Departmental and otherwise, through the Hudson's Bay Company for the last sixteen years without any expense to the Department.

Owing to the unprecedented mild weather in this part of B.C., only partial freezing of the Babine Lake has taken place this winter thereby rendering transportation much more difficult which, in all probability, will not occur again for many years. This has, no doubt, added to the cost of carrier services. During the spring, summer and fall, mail service is much more frequent than in the winter.

As the winter season is almost over, may I suggest...

Ottawa, February 1st, 1932.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 18th ultimo, I beg to say that a cheque in payment of your December quarter salary as teacher of the Fort Babine Indian Day School was forwarded to you on the 4th ultimo, addressed to Topley, B.C.

A cheque for $18.00 for janitor services at the Fort Babine School for the December quarter was forwarded to Mr. Agent Mortimer on the 5th ultimo.

Under separate cover, you will be forwarded an advance on your March quarter salary.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

C. O. Daly, Esq.,
Teacher,
Fort Babine Indian Day School,
Topley P.O., B.C.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa, February 17, 1932

Sir:

The Department has decided to grant Mr. C. O. Daly's request for a transfer from the Fort Babine Indian Day School. During the coming summer, he may move to the Skwah Indian Day School, in the New Westminster agency. The Indian agent is Mr. A. O'N. Daunt, New Westminster, B. C. Salary at the rate of $1000 per teaching year will be allowed in his case, and Mrs. Daly will be given $480 per annum for her services as field matron. Please inform them and ask for their acceptance of this offer in writing.

To replace the Dalys, the Department is offering the work at the Fort Babine Indian Day School to Mr. and Mrs. J. J. Moroney, who have been employed at the Skwah School. Mr. Moroney will receive $1100 for his services as teacher and Mrs. Moroney, $300 per annum as field matron.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

G. C. Mortimer, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hazelton,
B. C.

CANADA
Ottawa, March 19th, 1934.

Sir,-

Before the end of the current month, you will receive the March quarter salary cheques of the teachers of the Roche Deboule, Kitwanga, Hazelton, Glen Vowell and Fort Babine Indian Day Schools.

Provided the teachers have been on duty during the quarter, you can deliver their cheques to them and, at the same time, secure the March quarter returns, which should be promptly forwarded to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

G. C. Mortimer, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hazelton, B. C.
